Mr President, Commissioner, honourable Members, our primary objective is to ensure that Europe has a common agricultural policy even after 2013.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, for posterity, if the future has a memory, we are witnessing a genetic mutation of that Parliament, of that European Union, Mr President, which is entering a new era.

And I wouldn't want this discussion to be mistaken for a union or corporate one, because I am defending healthcare workers.
No, it's not like that. As a politician, I don't act on behalf of corporations or unions, I act on behalf of citizens.
I think of them when I make a choice, I think of their social rights, which are fundamental to me in Europe.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, we are facing an important compromise for Europe, even if the European Parliament has had to swallow a few bitter pills.
In substance, the text on renewables that emerged from the trialogue contains a clear definition of the objectives and, above all, of their mandatory nature.
The 2014 review clause is intended to provide greater flexibility in order to achieve the remaining reduction target of 20% and, if conditions permit, to push it up to 30% by 2020.

It should be emphasized that the most powerful and economically advantageous flexibility tool for Member States lies in national efficiency measures in the building, transport, and industrial sectors, as well as in the better use of electricity.
The mandatory 10% target for biofuels must be qualified with efficiency requirements in the transformation processes, by adopting environmental and social sustainability criteria.
The use of biomass should be directed towards non-controversial areas, towards conversion technologies that are more effective than first and second generation biofuels.

But the point here is not to claim that the Mediterranean diet should be imposed throughout the EU or to attempt to favor it over other dietary regimens that are better suited to different climates and regions outside the Mediterranean.
However, we have the task of protecting it, defining its content and characteristics, in order to defend it from imitations and external contaminations that could damage its image and value.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the crisis in the automotive sector has become a crisis for an entire industry, for the ancillary industries of other related sectors, for commercial networks and therefore for services, and it has dramatic employment prospects.

I think that the dramatic decline in these latest registrations for this month, reported as a 33% decrease in some member countries, a 20% decrease in others, etc., demonstrates that this is not a crisis of a technologically obsolete sector, nor does it originate within the sector or within any particular company due to managerial errors.
It is a systemic crisis and as such must be addressed urgently and decisively by the European institutions themselves.
Some remedies seem identified, but it is important how to implement them, with what resources and with what prospects for innovation.
It is certainly necessary to support demand, as consumption is the only driver of recovery.

But while this response of supporting consumption is being implemented, which is a medium-term response, I think we need to say that immediate credit support is required to resume production, pay for materials, and support employment, even in the face of a decline in alternatives and demand.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, I would like to thank the Czech Presidency, the Commission, the Chairman of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, Mrs Niebler, and my fellow Members of the European Parliament.

I would like to thank the rapporteurs of this energy package, the shadow rapporteurs, the Commission secretariat, and all its officials for their cooperation and expertise demonstrated in this dossier.
We can and must all be proud of the result achieved, I am, thinking about the effort made when I inherited the directive on the internal gas market, with problems that were not easy to solve.

I am pleased to have coincided my second experience as a European deputy with the final phase of this package, which I consider, among the most important dossiers of this legislature, to be in favor of European citizens, our voters.
The GASE directive, which will come into effect from 2011, brings significant innovations to the sector. It is important to highlight the achievement of the option as a major result.
ITO, which ensures the opening of markets and real progress towards a system that truly allows the European Union to speak with one voice on energy matters.
The OTI is the real innovation in this package and it is the one on which the European Parliament can be said to have achieved the best result.
The new gas directive gives a lot of importance to the gas authorities and the Agency.
This directive legitimizes the authorities in their role, particularly in those countries where they must start their work from scratch.

Therefore, it is of fundamental importance to have designed the role and competences of these bodies, to have given them broad powers, since it falls to the authorities to carry out the difficult task of controlling the common energy market.
Another element that was added during the trilogue phase is the exemption from the common rules of so-called closed systems, i.e., airports, hospitals, railway stations, industrial sites, etc.
They are subject to a more favorable regime, and this demonstrates the attention that the new directive pays to the needs of the European citizen.

In my opinion, it is the European citizen who will truly benefit from this directive, as, with the use of smart meters, they will have access to all information related to their bill and will be able to evaluate the best offer on the market and choose their own supplier.

particularly in the new member countries, where the creation of new infrastructure would also help to solve problems of long-standing dependence.

Once upon a time, we found ourselves in this Chamber to defend a food, cultural, and rural heritage stemming from a centuries-old tradition, an invaluable patrimony that the world envies us, representing a tremendous wealth for the economy and also for the identity of our Union.

A heritage that today risks finding itself in serious difficulty due to the Commission's and Council's desire to abolish the coupage ban for the production of ros wines, a desire born under strong pressure.

and which will be ratified without the possibility of intervention by the Parliament, the body that officially represents the millions of citizens among producers and consumers who will be affected by this initiative.

The Commission proposes to allow red wines to be produced simply by mixing red and white wines, as countries without our expertise and professionalism do, under the pretext of responding to international competition.
As the questioner, I emphasize that lowering the quality of our products, which are the result of centuries of tradition and research, of extremely important investments, and of passion,

Attention to detail is not the answer we need, especially in a time of economic crisis like this, when the average consumer is definitely more concerned about the price than about a label on the product.

To counterbalance this decision, it would be enough to find a name for the new product and inform consumers about the existence of two different types of ros, the varying quality of the products, and the importance of recognizing the work and efforts of industry professionals.
Who will pay for all this?

Does the Commission have any support programs in mind in this regard, or will producers still have to pay the price after being asked to compete on equal terms with low-cost competition in already difficult times?
I hope that the Commission and the Council will make the right choice and, if necessary, completely revise this procedure.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, allow me first of all to greet the chairman of the DTP party, Mr Ahmet Trk, who is here with us in the front row and is following the debate.
Dear Ahmet, know that we stand in solidarity with you, that we support the democratic struggle that your party is waging in Turkey for the recognition of the fundamental rights of the Kurdish people.
We recognize DTP as an indispensable tool for promoting democracy in Turkey and for this reason we firmly condemn the police operations that the Turkish government is carrying out.
Prime Minister Erdogan has ordered against you, imprisoning all three vice-presidents of the DTP, along with over 300 militants and sympathizers.
The DTP's victory in the recent local elections demonstrates that the DTP party is a party with strong democratic popular support.

The European Parliament, in its resolutions, has called on Prime Minister Erdogan to engage in direct discussions with the DTP, but his response has been more repression, more police, more authoritarianism, more imprisonment.
Everyone knows that my parliamentary group and the Left in Europe have so far supported Turkey's accession process to the European Union, while also supporting the reform process in that country.

However, I believe that in the last two years, and especially in recent months, Erdogan has shown another side, that of a leader compromised with the worst part of the Turkish army, who simply wants to massacre the Kurds.
The reform process is practically dead, prisons are filling up with Kurds. It is Erdogan himself who is closing any prospect of Turkey's accession.
It is his, and his alone, the responsibility for what is happening in Euro-Turkish relations and for the growing perplexity of European public opinion towards Turkey.

I want to send a very strong political message to Erdogan: either he makes the search for a negotiated political solution to the Kurdish question a priority, which, let it be clear, goes through direct negotiations with the DTP, or we will be the ones to call for the suspension of the accession negotiations with the European Union?

Turkey's path to EU membership goes through Diyarbakir and the DTP; otherwise, it will be we, those who have so far supported the accession process, who will call for a period of reflection that risks being definitive.

This did not happen everywhere.

I have already spoken about the Turin trial, where Swiss and Belgian bosses are on trial.
Everyone knew little was done, and it is primarily the industry that shirks its responsibilities, acting within the gaps of inertia and public authorities.
Examples of inertia are what happens, for instance, in Italy, in Brioni, where asbestos has not been removed, in Porto Marghera, in Cengio, where the dead are still being counted.
Today, the industry is asking the Commission to once again tolerate a derogation already granted for a limited time by the REACH regulation in 2006 for chrysotile asbestos fiber.

It is true that low-voltage electrolysis plants have limited applications and are only used in a few facilities, but in those cases, industrialists argue that there is no viable alternative, and that closing the plants would be inevitable.
An alternative to this process has been found in Sweden, using membrane replacement technology without myant for low voltage, and a similar approach has also been adopted for hydrogen production.
Why is it that in some states it is and in others it is not?
Because, as in the long battle to ban PCBs, there have been countless omissions and reticences, which were also supported by the Enterprise DG of the European Commission.
Once again, a good example was not set.
The 1999 directive banning asbestos required that the review of this authorization be preceded by an opinion from the Scientific Committee on Toxicology, which was never produced.
Is this how the Commission respects the directives?
Not to mention the union, which says it wasn't even consulted.
The European Parliament makes its own effort to appeal in fulfillment of others.

This resolution calls on the Commission to close a legislative gap by 2009 on banning second-hand products containing asbestos, roof tiles, aircraft parts and other items that should be disposed of permanently.
They set specific dates, once again, for a strategy to ban all types of asbestos by 2015, but these were goals already written in 1999.
Ten years have passed and people have continued to die.
The GUE had called for, among the first initiatives of this legislature, the establishment of a community fund for compensation to victims, and ad hoc funds for decontamination.
The request was specific towards the Commission, which today instead is cowering behind the will of the multinationals.
Instead, we need to move on to concrete facts and commitments.
Only when these comply with the same requirements as this resolution, only then can we be understanding.
Today this intention is not evident, which is why we are voting against granting the derogation.
Mr President, I wanted to convey to President Buzek the pride I feel at this moment in belonging to such an important institution as the European Parliament, which you preside over.
I believe that the sacrifices she has made in her country over the past twenty years, and which today represent those twelve countries mentioned earlier in this Assembly, give strength to Europe.
But I also want to convey my concern to you about listening to your program, within your speech, which should and I hope it will be, give strength to this Parliament.
I hope that what has been announced to us will come to fruition.

I hope that the next President of the European Commission, certainly President Barroso, will listen to her for the strong words she has spoken in order to ensure that this Parliament gives answers to more than

The 550 million citizens who have voted for us in this Europe, who wanted us and who want and demand answers from this Parliament, from all of us, are answers that Europe has certainly tried to give but has not fully succeeded in giving.
I manifest and set in motion my hopes on this activity of yours and I am certain that with you we will be able to achieve the certainties that you yourself have hosted us with.
Mr President, Commissioner, honourable Members, it is not my intention, nor that of my group, which supported and wanted this debate, to transfer Italian internal policy issues to the European level.

The issue of freedom of information concerns us all, it concerns the European Union, which can and must regulate the matter at Community level, in order to counteract political and economic conditioning and to ensure genuine pluralism of information.

The Italian anomaly, where the prime minister is also the owner of some of the most important private networks, lies precisely in the existence of a dangerous intertwining of media, political, and economic powers.

This is precisely why we are calling for European regulatory intervention, an intervention that, far from being an act of anti-Italian sentiment, serves to protect the pluralism of information, preventing concentrations and conflicts of interest.

For this reason, today we are asking the Commission to intervene as soon as possible, as this Parliament has also requested in the past, to equip the European Union with common rules to protect the freedom of information for all European citizens.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, I am aware that on 30 September last, the Commission presented a study on media pluralism indices in the Member States.
But in 2008 a report was voted on, with Marianne Micko as rapporteur, which called on the European Commission and the Member States to protect, and I quote verbatim, the multiplicity of resources.
of opinions on the media, to defend the pluralism of information, to guarantee all citizens of the European Union equal access to free and diversified information media.

Even earlier, in 2004, a report was voted on in Parliament, with Bogert Kvack as rapporteur, on the risks of violation in the European Union of freedom of expression and information, which called on the Commission to present a communication on guaranteeing media pluralism in all Member States.
To date, the Commission has not yet provided clear answers to Parliament's requests.

You will notice, Commissioner, that I have not mentioned my country or my Prime Minister, but here, as a European citizen, I am asking you what the Commission intends to do at the European level to ensure that media pluralism is guaranteed in all Member States.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the debate on the vote that took place yesterday in the Committee on the Environment has been reported many times.
I would like it to be evident instead that it cannot all be attributed to a single extremist and ideological position.

We have heard many different positions from our colleagues, which are much more varied, much more detailed, much more sensible, and therefore, being more in line with reality, I believe they are more capable of providing real answers.
Science as a totem does not exist. When this mistake was made of identifying a problem in such an ideological way, no answers were given, but rather problems were created.
Disasters and Europe should be a teacher in this regard and not repeat the same mistakes, even if they are dressed up in different clothes and with labels that seem ostensibly much more friendly.

I must point out that the same directive on emissions trading specifically provides that the European Union's virtuous path will be subject to an evaluation by the Commission based on the outcomes of the conference.
We must go to the conference with strong positions and clear ideas, but also striving to fairly divide the interests.

We must also support the efforts of all industrialised countries, primarily, which must adopt equivalent emission reduction targets, but also not forgetting what our colleague Grossette so clearly pointed out, which is now the subject of our discussion.

But among developing countries we cannot fail to make distinctions: there are developing countries, truly, there are countries that have now emerged economies, I am talking about India, China, Brazil.
These are countries that cannot fail to also assume their commitments.

I, on the other hand, strongly demand that if an agreement is not reached in Copenhagen, the European Union must continue to ensure the allocation of free allowances to the sectors at risk under Directive 2003 EC.

These are fundamental points; we want the Kyoto Protocol itself to retain its environmental significance and, above all, we want to prevent the creation of a financial bubble at the expense of our European companies.
It is very important for two reasons: first, the research topic, which concerns the fight against neurodegenerative diseases, and second, the method of joint programming in research.
We would obviously have preferred, and this was stated and the subject of our question, a more direct participation of Parliament in the pilot project.

If we are not to halt proceedings and must press ahead, we do, however, demand guarantees that our opinion will be taken into account by the Competitiveness Council and that a more certain legal basis will be clarified for the future, for full involvement of Parliament and for more comprehensive ownership of this research matter.

Now we must intervene with adequate means and resources to prevent and eradicate such a widespread scourge as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and other diseases that are destined to grow in the face of an aging population.
We ask that focus be placed on large-scale studies, both for diagnosis and for identifying treatments.

Research on biomarkers, on early diagnosis methods based on a multidisciplinary approach, the establishment of extensive databases, the search for curative drugs and appropriate care and service models seem to be fundamental.

I would like to make just one appeal here: do not neglect either the subjectivity of patients, which is too often excluded in this type of disease, or the involvement of patient and family associations.
From a methodological standpoint, we believe that joint research projects are very important because they address a fundamental need: that of concentrating efforts and resources.
overcome those fragmentations, those duplications and thus be able to create a critical mass sufficient to produce appropriate results for this type of research.

If one considers that in other areas of the world, joint public and private efforts amount to investing tens of millions of euros, we realize how much we still have to do and how much we need to do, converging on projects.

on strategic lines and shared programs between states and Europe, and on common programs between public and private entities, without neglecting the international framework that connects us with major scientific institutions worldwide.
What are the novelties of the Stockholm Programme compared to the Hague Programme, a fair balance between rights and security, and legal protection in both criminal and civil law?

Security is a right: not to be attacked in the workplace, to walk down the street without risking one's life, not to be subjected to violence because one is a woman, not to be exposed to acts of terrorism.
The states and Europe must ensure security.
But a security measure that undermines the guarantees of freedom is a measure that denies certainty to the law and is therefore a source of insecurity and barbarism.
Guantanamo.
Europe is the homeland of rights.
The Stockholm Programme defines them in great detail.

Today, there is a just balance between the discipline of crime suppression on one hand, and the daily lives of citizens, their family, social, economic, work, and study relationships, all regulated by civil law and civil justice.
This is the Europe of the citizen.
It must be built within the states and in the community institutions.
European society is more united, and mobility is more intense than is commonly believed.
Mobility is now a right.
Conflicts between states are not impermeable walls, they are networks through which society filters every day.
The first is that Stockholm provides the institutional framework for judicial cooperation, mutual recognition, a European justice system, and a national one.
it is the Community one, a European, national and Community right, a European citizen, a European judge, the national one and the Community one.

European rules are dictated by Community regulations and the case law of European courts, but they also stem from the behavior of workers, businesses, students, national magistrates, and European networks among justice professionals.
Bottom up, therefore, and this process from below is what the Stockholm Programme aims to support.
Parliament has made a great effort with this resolution, which I hope will be supported here by a broad, unified vote, which we have worked on intensively.
The Council should respectfully take this into account.
Lisbon is not yet in implementation, but it is there, very much present.
Let the Council be ambitious, Mr. Minister, and make the most of what we have developed here and the wealth of suggestions that emerge from it.
In this report on budgetary control, I must acknowledge the very important work carried out by the Commission, the excellent work of the rapporteur, and I must also mention the political cohesion.

This is because from the very beginning we wanted to send a very clear message: we intend to work with great rigor to ensure transparency, correctness, and legality in the management of public funds and, therefore, in the verification of budgets.
There have been some very significant steps forward with the Council, which initially did not want to respond.
I personally acknowledge this to the Swedish Presidency, which has always wanted to demonstrate that it operates towards transparency and correctness.
So we expect further progress from this point of view, because obviously it is absolutely unacceptable, especially with the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty.

I do not want Parliament in Lisbon to be without information and news, precisely in order to verify budgets and public funds, in the interests not only of the European Union, but also of all European citizens.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, we were in Ramallah when we received the news that Europe had adopted a new decision on the Middle East peace process.
We saw the hopeful smiles of the Palestinian representatives.

It was an intense few days of emotions and suffering, etched on the faces of children clinging to the window bars of their homes, on a street in Hebron, the ghost street that cannot be crossed by any Palestinian.

The suffering of an 85-year-old woman evicted from her occupied home, forced to sleep in the cold in a tent placed in the garden of what used to be her home, the suffering in the faces of those Palestinians who had built a farm with European funds, which was then destroyed by Israeli soldiers.
Israel has the right to be an independent state, but the Palestinians also have the right to have a homeland, a state, a passport.
The decision by the Council of Europe represents a significant step forward, but action is needed immediately.
The conflict between Israel and Palestine is the tip of the iceberg of a larger conflict.
On the last day, which was supposed to be the visit, the Israeli authorities prevented us, the delegation from the European Parliament, from visiting the Gaza Strip.
I believe that on this issue, the High Representative, Baroness Ashton, must intervene to make the protest of democratic Europe heard.

I thank President De Rossa, who led the delegation, and all the other members of the delegation, because during the days we were in Palestine, the weak of Palestine could see and hear the face and words of a Europe that defends rights and wants and must do more.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the European Union is committed to the fight against terrorism in all its dimensions.
When it comes to combating terrorist crimes, it is essential to ensure that fundamental rights are fully respected and that the measures taken to combat terrorism are adequate and effective.

The rights of the defence and fundamental procedural guarantees must therefore be fully respected by the Union's institutions, even when they define lists of persons and entities, in this case linked to someone.
Al Qaeda, subject to restrictive measures, and it is equally essential that these measures are subject to appropriate democratic and parliamentary control, as rightly prescribed by the Lisbon Treaty.

It is therefore clear that, as also stated by the Parliament's legal service, any measure of this type will have to follow the codecision procedure, allowing the representatives of European citizens to fully exercise their legislative and supervisory role.
Mr. President, I would like to avoid continuing to list the reasons for our disagreement with the Iranian government.
I will only take the liberty of pointing out, since it has not been mentioned here, that one of the most serious violations of civil rights is that against young people.
The Iranian government, having signed the United Nations treaty in defense of children, continues to impose capital punishment on minors.
I would like, after this debate, for Baroness Ashton to commit to setting out a common line for the whole of Europe and the whole of the European Parliament.
European attention on the events in Iran and, on the other hand, the interparliamentary commission with the Iranian government acknowledging that the course of action needs to change.

I participated with friends Scuria and Tatarella in the protest that we had formulated against the Commission, which, despite issuing an official statement, declared its intention to go to Iran, having instead peremptorily requested that there be an opportunity to meet with the opposition and engage in dialogue with it.

I would like the Commission to turn a new leaf from this moment and establish relations of aid, support, and dialogue with the representatives of the opposition who are in exile, not least Mrs. Miriam Rajavi, who represents this reality.
This is what the European Community should do, rather than sanctions.

I am speaking in order to highlight the severity of the deindustrialization situations that are affecting various industrial centers in Sicily, particularly the automotive industry in Terni Mareese, Fiat Group, and the petrochemical industry in Gela, Eni Group.
The industry is struggling and damaged by competition from the low-wage system within some EU countries, and it is also suffering from Asian competition.
In view of the severe deindustrialization processes that are manifesting themselves in widespread areas of the Union, I believe that the time has come to reconsider the policy of non-intervention.
The European Commission has so far taken action and is beginning to implement a package of measures to support relevant and strategic European industries.
This appeal is primarily directed at the European Commission and Industry Commissioner Tajani.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the topic of good fiscal governance, while always being of great importance, has taken on even greater relevance and significance following the major economic and financial crisis of two years ago.
International, G20 and European leaders have discussed this issue and continue to do so, particularly when addressing the fight against tax evasion and tax havens.
All of this is important, it is a sign of commitment and determination, but one must not delude oneself into thinking that an announcement is enough.
A serious and continuous policy is needed.
There are still many problems.
Is it really still too easy to buy or set up a shell company to evade taxes?
Just take a look online, there are thousands of sites offering companies for purchase, even in European Union countries.
Often, an email with a scanned photocopy of the passport attached is all that is needed to open a company.
The practice of creating fictitious legal entities to evade taxation must be stopped.
The report I am presenting is based on the European Commission's communication on tax good governance of 28 April 2009.
The report moves towards putting forward concrete proposals and calls for a strong commitment from the European Commission and the Council to implement these proposals.
The fight against tax havens, tax evasion, and illicit capital flight must be considered a priority of the European Union.
Hence the principle of good governance, which is based on transparency, exchange of information, cross-border cooperation, and fair tax competition.
The point is that there is a need for ever greater cooperation and fiscal collaboration in the European Union.
The overall goal we must set for ourselves is to achieve an automatic exchange of information on a global and multilateral scale, starting, of course, with the European Union.
Bank secrecy must be abolished entirely in the countries of the European Union, and the derogation regime from these agreements must be ended without further delay.
a temporary measure that authorizes the application of a withholding tax at source, often evaded or underestimated, in place of the exchange of information.
I do not wish to dwell on the concrete proposals contained in the report.
I would like to emphasize that we still need to expand the scope of the 2003 Savings Directive in particular, combat VAT fraud, and establish a public Union register.
The Commission has also proposed to establish a monitoring system that would account for individuals or companies that have set up companies or opened accounts in tax havens.

The European Union must also speak with a single voice internationally, and fight for the improvement of OECD regulations to achieve the automatic exchange of information, instead of the exchange on request.

Commissioner Kovac, you have also heard the other reports, we need a strong commitment from the Commission and we need, at this moment, for the new Commission, at the handover, to have these priorities emphasized.
We will hold the Council and the European Commission accountable for their work.
I thank my colleagues and especially the shadow rapporteurs for their contribution to this work, which I hope will be approved by Parliament.

Mr. President, I must admit that when we talk about fighting terrorism, discussing only intelligence and technology, I always have the impression that we are examining the issue inadequately, as if we wanted to cure a disease by focusing only on its symptoms and not on its causes.
Is it not time to address the problem of terrorism by targeting the heart of the issue, rather than merely focusing on its external phenomenology?

Tackling the heart of the problem means, for example, becoming aware that terrorism is also a direct manifestation of the inability or unwillingness of ethnic groups to integrate into the European cultural fabric.
I wonder and I ask this Parliament: do we want to discuss terrorism?
Let this Parliament then have the courage to engage in a political debate on the degree of integration of Muslims in Europe and their willingness to share Western values, rights, and freedoms.
In this regard, I have submitted a question to the Commission on the full veil to encourage this House to openly address the issue.
It seems to me that there is no will whatsoever to address the issue.
I wonder, and I ask you, honourable colleagues, from all political groups, if not on these topics, on which other issues should the political leadership of the peoples of Europe pronounce itself?

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the conclusion of negotiations with Croatia by 2010 is a feasible objective, and the report does an excellent job of highlighting in a balanced way the progress made and the steps that still need to be taken.
Now it is the justice sector that still requires incisive reforms.
In fact, it is not enough to complete the necessary systemic reforms, pass new laws, and cooperate as needed with the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia.
I insist on the need to create a genuine legal culture and mentality in line with European standards.

The independence of the judiciary, central problem, the training, recruitment and career of magistrates, that is, the absence of various types of influence exerted by the government on judges, become crucial.
I appeal to the Commission to consider the need for decisive measures in this regard during the final phase of the negotiation.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, Croatia's accession to the European Union accentuated the consolidation of a European identity capable of expressing the common values of the new Europe without obscuring, but rather integrating, the specificities of its many souls.

The Republic of Croatia has made commendable efforts in adapting to the required parameters, particularly in combating organized crime through new anti-mafia measures, but it needs to make further efforts, especially in the judicial sector, before the 2010 negotiations can be concluded.

Further steps can be taken by the institutions of the Republic of Croatia to align with the provisions of the first protocol of the European Convention on Human Rights signed in Paris in 1952, by considering the restitution of nationalized property to its rightful owners.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, once again, recently, there has been an environmental disaster in Italy involving the Lambro River and the Po River.
Recently, the Court of Justice in Luxembourg condemned Italy for the danger to public health, for the illegal disposal of waste, and for its failure to control waste collection in Campania.
And recent news of the increase in leukaemia in Taranto due to Ilva, as well as the disposal of asbestos in schools in Crotone, and dioxin in Campania.
It's an ongoing environmental disaster.

I firmly ask the Commission what it intends to do to bring the Italian government into line with the standards of the European Union directives, particularly in light of the Court of Justice's ruling the other day.
The city of Naples has been exposed to public ridicule for many weeks and many months all over the world.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, this debate is not ritualistic, but rather aims to be very concrete and to ask clear and precise questions about how many resources are needed and where they should come from. I hope, and Parliament hopes, that the answers will be equally clear and precise at today's and the upcoming Council meetings on 12 and 25 March.

We want to firmly tell the Commission and the Council that the European Union, which has raised the flag of the fight against atmospheric emissions and the climate challenge before the world, has a duty of consistency today if it does not want to lose credibility.
He must do everything possible to ensure that these objectives are achieved.

We must be very clear that talking about a low-emission economy means a kind of Copernican revolution for the production system, it means changing many things, having clear priorities, political will, but above all adequate resources and tools.
We also know that this Copernican revolution is essential for our production system, European industry, to remain competitive.

I mean that in many countries, in many research centers, in many universities, the intelligences are ready, the capabilities are there, the will is there; it is now a matter of turning on this engine.
Everyone has to do it, said the Commissioner, said the Council, the Member States have to do it, the entrepreneurs, the private forces.
But I believe that the indispensable task of putting together this complex partnership lies with the European Union.
To address the employment problem in a constructive way, the watchwords for Community actions are three: react, evolve, and protect.

React, that is, abandon the celebratory tones of Euro-propaganda to address in a concrete way the problems that afflict EU citizens, ensuring a direct link between the world of training and the needs of the market and the territory, requalifying in young people the perception of manual professions.

To evolve, or rather, to make the EU 2020 strategy a positive synthesis between the demands of businesses and those of workers, in favor of a labor market where the flexibility of contractual forms responds to the instability of market demand.

Protect, that is, give work to those who have lost it, first and foremost to our citizens. The Member States must therefore evaluate immigration policies based on the real need for immigration and, with 23 million unemployed, we should consider the possibility of blocking extra-Community immigration for a few years.
I see no other way to protect our jobs and our social system.
What is needed is concreteness, courage and decentralization.
Mr President, this is an oral amendment to point 13, where it invites the Commission to verify, in the current situation, the possibility of providing verified humanitarian aid to the situation.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, I would like to emphasise once again the importance of the written declaration on corruption that I proposed together with four other Members of Parliament and that more than half of the European Parliament approved, in order to commit the Council and the Commission to truly effective legislation on corruption.

I returned from a visit to Greece on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control, and one of the reasons for the Greek structural crisis is certainly the squandering of public money, a situation that also occurs in Italy.

Eroded by corruption, as has become evident in recent days, corruption that primarily revolves around the illegal management of public funds, the relationship between a segment of the political class, a segment of entrepreneurs, and white-collar organized crime.

It is important that the European Parliament exerts all its pressure on the Commission and the Member States, that the Member States that do not comply are sanctioned, and that the European institutions responsible for controlling corruption and fighting organized crime are strengthened.
In relation to male and female, we know that this difference is even more pronounced in the context of autonomous activities.
In fact, women have all too often been forced to sacrifice their professional ambitions in the name of taking on the role and workload that comes with absolute dedication to the family.

To solve this problem, I believe it is necessary to implement measures such as those contained in the directive we are discussing, but with a clear focus on the guiding star of the family. Only this can give meaning and hope for success to these very measures.

Releasing women from the distressing dilemma of choosing between being a mother, wife, and entrepreneur means making the burden of family work less onerous and addressing concrete problems through positive and specific measures to support families.
Putting the family at the center, otherwise any package of measures will be a disjointed set of interventions, ultimately useless.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, Commissioner, today we are discussing organ transplantation, which is undoubtedly one of the most positive aspects of progress in the healthcare sector.
But on the other hand, it opens up a whole series of problems regarding the rights of the donor and the patient, which need to be addressed on an ethical, social, legal, and economic level.

It is a matter of activating a virtuous path that addresses the serious imbalance between the need for and quantity of available organs, without undermining the principle of free and voluntary donation.
all forms of commercialization and illegal trafficking, ensuring the quality and safety of organs intended for transplantation, with measures that balance confidentiality with traceability.

It goes without saying that, in a context of cross-border exchanges and significant differences between the transplant systems adopted in the various Member States, these objectives can only be achieved by promoting coordination and cooperation.
In this regard, I believe it would be very important to establish a European database and adopt common quality and safety standards.
We must be careful, however, not to introduce unnecessary forms of rigidity or create additional bureaucratic burdens that compromise what is currently being done correctly and effectively.
Here, it would not only be contrary to our objectives.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, I thank the rapporteur for the excellent work done on the European Union's accession to the Convention on Human Rights, which has reached its first agreement in two years.

It is a benefit for European citizens because it will result in a new court outside the European Union to ensure that the rights of European citizens are always respected by the European Union and the Member States.

By virtue of the principle of democracy, the European Union and its member states must always have the right to defend themselves, which is why I believe it is essential that every nation that adheres to the convention should have a judge who explains the context of each appeal.

I believe that the European Parliament has an informal body with the purpose of coordinating the exchange of information between the Parliament and the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council, and it is important that the Parliament is also consulted and involved in the negotiation process.
I would also add that European citizens have the right to understand the mechanisms of this accession, just as they have the right to know what their rights are.

Therefore, I believe it is essential that the Council of Europe and the European Union consider developing guidelines, with a clear explanation of all the effects and implications that membership will entail.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, 170 measures in five years, numbers that are too ambitious for a programme lacking a true connotation, especially on certain issues.

On immigration, the program, beyond the official documents, reveals an embarrassing weakness: what is the point of promising and strengthening organizations and agencies if there is no political strategy in place?

A truly useful strategy that must be based on some fundamental points: fighting illegal immigration along the southern border, sharing the burden of combating illegal immigration among all European Union states, implementing agreements with third countries, and above all recognizing that immigration is not a resource during times of crisis.
On the Parliament's home page, we read that more than 20% of young people in Europe are unemployed.
In a continent with 25 million unemployed people, the Commissioner for Home Affairs says that the issue of migration must be based on solidarity.

Instead, we must think concretely and realistically: today, the priority is to give work to our citizens; everything else is empty rhetoric that does not help the integration of immigrants, nor does it help our people.
I would like to take this opportunity to request the Presidency to take action to make long-term connections more effective.
Air travel between Strasbourg and European capitals should be direct and not continue to cause inconvenience to those who have to take three or four planes to get to Strasbourg.
Please take appropriate action.

The financial crisis of recent months and years, the new Lisbon Treaty with its new tasks, and the challenge we have set ourselves with Europe 2020 require the mobilisation of new and substantial financial resources.
The paradox we are also witnessing in this debate is that, at the present time, both the Commission and the Council appear to be silent, unable to make a choice and determine decisions.
However, we know that if we want to emerge from the difficult economic and social phase, if we want to tackle the major issues of the environment, the development of cohesion policy, and the
If we want to improve agriculture in the coming years, we need to invest more in Europe and in Europe's function, and therefore in Europe's essential function, namely its budget.
For this reason, we must not be afraid to discuss, even during a period of financial constraints, investing more in resources.
having the strength and ability to develop a debate and a comparison that links the issue of more resources to the issue of higher quality and greater flexibility in their use.
But this is the challenge that lies ahead of us.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the European Parliament is called upon, as we know, to express itself definitively on food information for consumers.
It should be immediately noted that this was an objectively laborious, lengthy, and controversial legislative process that could not be shortened.

The aim is indeed to harmonise Community law on foodstuffs through regulations designed to make information transparent to consumers, avoiding misleading choices that could potentially harm their health.

The report by Mr Sommer, who deserves credit for his efforts to summarise multiple requirements, therefore aims to remedy disputes and the various information systems in force in the countries of the Union.

It is no coincidence that national regulations to date differ in the designations of the nature of the regulations put up for sale, generating a different system from country to country, and also fueling unfair competition to the detriment of potential consumers.
An attempt was thus made, based on the proposal of the European Commission, to give new life to the current legislation, involving both the food industry and consumers.
At the same time, the report commits the European food industry to clarify mandatory indications, the indication and presentation of food and nutritional values.

In a globalized market, the European Union could not avoid the necessary innovation of food legislation, in order to better protect food trade and safeguard against increasingly invasive and fierce international competition.

It is not new that there is more frequent talk about the dangers of food products that, when transported, bear labels and indications that often do not meet food requirements, yet are still marketed as food and beneficial for human health.
Commissioner, we have requested this oral question and a parliamentary resolution to make it clear to the Commission that a long-term solution is not possible.
Within the framework of the Stockholm Programme, it is very important to build a widespread European legal culture throughout our territory.

I would like to say straight away that this is important, but also that, in view of the communication that the Commission will have to produce for us on future pilot projects, as has been said, we would like to clarify a few concepts.
First of all, that the consultations begin early, the Parliament's consultations in the meantime, and that they reach the initial phase, when the idea starts to be drawn up.
of these future projects, because we do not arrive too late, when the projects are already formulated quite completely.
And I say this because we have some fundamental observations to make.
Considering that the national magistrate, the lawyer of the individual States, is today a decisive pawn in the construction of Europe.
Because by interpreting national rights in a European context, it provides the conditions for resolving conflicts and regulating the daily lives of citizens.
This thus fosters a European awareness among all those living in these territories, so that they can experience firsthand the rights of European citizens.
It is an advantage that the introduction of European elements into all the rights of the States, and therefore especially of Community law, makes citizens' lives better.
They offer real advantages to address a range of problems that would otherwise remain unresolved.
And I would like to say with this that we would like to turn the framework around a bit.
For example, we would not agree that these projects are Erasmus-style, because the number of judges and lawyers involved in Erasmus-style projects would be
very low, as it must be, due to the high costs of physical mobility in this field, and therefore not very relevant in the overall context of the magistracies.
But the most important issue concerns the term familiarization courses that we introduced in our document.

Judges are not schoolchildren sitting in a classroom who can be lectured to; they are mature, highly professional individuals with little time available for this, who cannot be easily moved, but they bring

they must be stimulated so that their knowledge can be measured against the new problems of European law and European culture, creating conditions for exchange that are predominantly virtual rather than real.
And starting not so much from a general approach, but from individual cases, from the individual problems that magistrates and lawyers face, which are the problems that citizens have to face.
that are new and that must stimulate professional growth for these legal professionals, within a context of effectively increased motivation.
We must contribute to the autobiographical reflection on their experiences, on what they have learned, in order to respond to the challenges that Europe is presenting in positive terms.

As you can see, Mr President, Commissioner, we intend to introduce something new into the tradition of the courses that have been offered to us so far and which we consider to be ineffective for this purpose.

We need to know how much funding is available and who has doubts about the idea, as stated in the communication, of a central European institution governing this process, because we are in favor of a grassroots movement rather than centralization.
This is a new approach.

What we mean, however, is that if a European mentality is not formed among magistrates and lawyers, who in this way offer their services to justice and to the citizens who demand it, we will not make Europe.
So this is not just an important card for European justice, it is an important card for the entire development of European unity.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the proposal on the rights of passengers travelling by bus aims to improve and protect passengers, particularly those with disabilities or reduced mobility.
This is the first regulation on the rights of bus passengers and should guarantee passengers the same rights as in the rail and air sectors.
The position at second reading aims to establish a set of rights for passengers who choose to travel by bus.

I agree with the line taken by the rapporteur, Mr Cancin, whom I thank for the excellent work he has done, and I believe that the scope of the regulation should be amended to exclude regional services when they are integrated with urban and suburban services.
It would be right and proper to guarantee passengers' rights in the event of accidents, cancellations or delays in departure, as had already been decided at first reading by Parliament.

Equally important is the issue of information on passengers' rights. It would be useful, in fact, to provide passengers with information on connections with other modes of transport, which will also ensure dialogue between passenger transport services by bus and those by rail.

Regarding disabled individuals, people with reduced mobility must be guaranteed the utmost protection, and I would propose a 24-hour deadline instead of 48 hours for requesting assistance, as well as greater guarantees for compensation and replacement of mobility aids in case of loss or damage.
Furthermore, taking into account the needs of passengers with reduced mobility, any architectural barriers should be removed and existing infrastructure should be improved to make them accessible.
This regulation aims to improve the competitiveness of the bus sector, promote intermodality, but above all to improve the travel conditions for passengers.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Sterckx, who has done an excellent job on this report, which deals with extending the free movement of goods in the maritime sector for navigation within the European Union.
I share the rapporteur's aim of this directive, which is to exempt all intra-EU maritime transport of goods from unnecessary administrative formalities.

In fact, in order to have a European maritime space without borders, it is not only important that the various competent authorities cooperate satisfactorily, but also that the various simplification systems are applied at the same time.
This is necessary to ensure the smooth functioning of the entire European maritime space without borders, to make the transport of goods by sea more attractive and to be used in an optimal manner.

The harmonization of administrative procedures between Member States will allow for smoother navigation between the various ports of the European Union and will boost maritime freight traffic, which currently accounts for less than 10% of the total.
To date, navigation continues to be hindered by the administrative formalities imposed on it.
Electronic systems should therefore come into operation as quickly as possible, because it would allow for a faster data exchange system.

Moreover, interoperability is important for achieving real administrative simplification, in fact, the initiation of information via email is not entirely efficient and is useless if the information systems are not technically interoperable.
As for the language, I believe that the use of a common language would certainly benefit European maritime navigation.
This would make communication faster, causing less confusion and fewer administrative delays.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, I would first of all like to offer my special congratulations to our rapporteur, Mr Kramer, because we all know that we have truly achieved a result that sometimes seemed unexpected.
I would like to remind you that this dossier was considered to be at real risk of conciliation proceedings.
So we have also heard from the Commissioner's words that it is evident to everyone that we are dealing with a job that was complex and required a lot of time.
Suffice it to say that this work brings us to the fifth and most important amendment to the directive on industrial emissions, which was first issued in 1996.
I believe that these few data points alone tell us everything about the shortcomings and even the flaws of this legislation.

I would like to remind you that a directive that is difficult to implement, with nine Member States affected by infringement procedures, has a scope that is so extensive that it is sometimes inappropriate.

Let's not hide the fact that all of this has involved significant efforts, required sacrifices from all the institutions involved, from all the political groups, from all the national delegations, and has often placed us before truly difficult choices.

But I am here this evening to say with conviction that, in my opinion, we have achieved the best possible results to protect competition, the environment, and European industrial and employment policy.
On the one hand, we have a directive that imposes common obligations on all Member States, but on the other hand, we also have a directive that allows for the necessary flexibility.

I truly hope that the results of this recast will be the immediate reduction of administrative burdens and, in the medium term, the improvement of environmental performance and the strengthening of the European industry.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, I would like to highlight the situation in which the Church is facing a reality to which, for too long, we have not given the importance it deserves.
namely the instability in Central Asia, which unfortunately is growing, while the hopes for democracy and economic progress, at least in some of these countries, prove to be particularly fragile.

Kyrgyzstan has suffered in the past month from extremely violent clashes that will leave, at least in the immediate future, a legacy of interethnic hatreds that will make the stabilization of the country even more difficult than it was before.

The task of the international community and the European Union in particular, as has already been said, is to assist Kishida in every possible way in three areas by providing immediate aid to the victims.

Secondly, through economic aid of the longest possible duration, the European Union, within the framework of its strategy for growth and development, must be able to contribute effectively to supporting the needs of growth and development.

strategy for Central Asia and the instruments implemented in this context, through political support to back the process of returning to constitutional legality and the establishment of a genuine rule of law.
The constitutional referendum, which has been in crisis since June 28 under obviously very difficult conditions, can be considered a first step on the road to a return to constitutional order.

The electoral process on June 28, among other things, received a positive assessment from the OSCE observation commission, which obviously took into account the special conditions under which the referendum was held.
The new constitutional structure of the Church will be more oriented towards a parliamentary system than towards a presidential system.
This will perhaps allow for a better consideration of the country's varied ethnic composition and the need to gather consensus from the various components of such a fragmented and diverse country.
The European Union and Kyrgyzstan are bound by a partnership and cooperation agreement, which provides for regular meetings of a parliamentary cooperation committee.
It is our hope that our interparliamentary relations can resume as soon as possible with the participation of a democratically elected Parliament.
In the immediate term, as mentioned, the country needs stability and our political and economic support; let's try not to be stingy with either.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the European Council, which no one has voted for, today also has a rotating presidency in the hands of a government that has been dismissed by its own citizens.

This alone would be enough to understand why Europe is experiencing a profound crisis, an Europe that has now become a political paradox in the hands of a political elite with which citizens no longer identify.
The non-presidency program of Belgium talks about structural reforms, employment growth, financial stability and competitiveness and the chosen instrument would be the EU 2020 strategy.
The current crisis, however, should push Europe towards very different ingredients from those that led to failure.

A general rethinking is necessary, because the crisis is not a reflection of decline, but rather the death certificate of the European social model that Euro-propaganda would instead like to administer as a cure.
Today Europe is an immense building that is collapsing in on itself under the weight of democracy, centralism, and obstacles to free enterprise.
To emerge from the crisis, Europe must change its vocabulary: more decentralization, less bureaucracy, more practicality and attention to the real problems of citizens.
Everything else will only inevitably accelerate the decline.

I would like to emphasize in this speech of mine how the progressive erosion of European farmers' incomes at the expense of growing problems in agriculture and farming is an opportunity for the future.

The profit margins of the agro-industrial chain are creating a worrying economic marginalization of those working in the agricultural sector, resulting in the abandonment of the very activities they are engaged in.
A change of direction is therefore necessary, which the European Commission itself acknowledges, and which the report under consideration this morning in the Chamber
The approval of the Chamber this morning, to which I wish to express my support, underlines this with ample reasons and suggestions of a legislative and departmental nature.
It is indeed necessary to fight against global speculation on raw materials and ensure the security of supplies.

Moreover, better price transparency must be ensured, which not only does justice to dignified farmers, but also corrects the strong imbalances that exist in terms of negotiating power and prevents abuses among the different operators.
Agriculture must reaffirm itself as a sector of economic and social stability and regain its power in the European Union's market context.
Mobilism and myopia: this is the diagnosis of the malaise affecting Europe 27 today.

The stagnation is also due to the fact that for every four young people without a job in Italy and 16 million unemployed people in the Eurozone, the noise of the Euro propaganda in recent months has not been followed by any concretely effective action.

The shortcoming lies in the fact that Europe, in indicating the way out of the crisis, has not only represented the usual recipe, but has completely lost sight of the most authentically territorial dimension of the economic and social cohesion policy.

Only by placing the territory at the center of political action, only by respecting its unique cultural vocations, can European policies for development and employment restart, drawing nourishment from the natural energies that each geographical area expresses: districts, small and medium-sized enterprises, and craftsmanship.
To solve the employment problem, we must first think small, invest in local entities, and prioritize subsidiarity, while protecting a heritage made up of linguistic and cultural diversity.
If the needle of European Brussels does not guide its policy towards the territory, the shipwreck of the Europroject is a certainty.
Mr President, in the construction of a Europe of rights, freedom of information, pluralism of information, and independence of information hold a central place.
Has Commissioner Sir, Commissioner Madam, noticed that there is a country in the European Union, which was also a founding member with the Treaty of Rome, where there is no
It is a pluralism of information, where a Prime Minister directly or indirectly controls public and private television and the press.
What kind of democratic electoral competition can there be in a country where a president, the Council, and a political party control the media?
What kind of democracy can there be in a country where they want to pass a law within days that does not allow journalists to publish judicial news?
Forget Watergate, forget the press as the regime's watchdog, a lapdog, what kind of democratic country is it where the Internet is to be controlled?
What kind of democratic country is this, where those who oppose the dominant ideology are sidelined and the free expression of thought and dissent are not guaranteed?

We are not describing the Sudan of Bocassa, the Romania of Ceausescu and the Italy of Berlusconi, where unfortunately this happens, also because the European Commission does not have the courage to express an autonomous and free position with respect to the Member States.
The completion of the internal market for postal services by the end of this year is an important step, but it would be a step forward for growth.

it would be appropriate for the Commission to carry out an impact assessment, as some colleagues who spoke before me have pointed out, on the opening up of the postal market, in order to better understand the needs of citizens.

How does the Commission intend to protect the right of European citizens living in hard-to-reach areas, such as mountainous or rural regions, to receive their mail regularly, and what instruments does the Commission intend to adopt to ensure this happens?
I also believe that this directive, which already exists, should not be used to justify the problem of social dumping.
It is the Member States that must implement the directive and they have all the tools to do so.
Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, today's debate on readmission agreements cannot avoid the now thorny issue concerning the agreement between the European Union and Libya.
We know that one side of the agreement is focused on combating illegal immigration.
We are concerned because, to date, the Commission has told us very little about this, despite the Lisbon Treaty requiring the Commission to promptly inform Parliament.
As is well known, Libya has not signed the Geneva Convention on Human Rights, and has not demonstrated any behavior in line with international law to date.

I think of the case of Eritrean immigrants detained inhumanely in the Libyan center of Brak, or the closure of the UNHCR offices, but I think above all of what happened last week, when a Libyan Republic patrol boat opened fire on Libya.

A very serious justification, which makes us think that the agreement signed between Libya and Italy, which led to an invasion of Libya, was an act of violence against an Italian fishing boat from the Navy of Mazzara del Vallo, present in international waters.

it also provides for the deportation of immigrants to Libya without provisions for the right to request asylum and individual case-by-case examination of individual situations, and also includes the possibility of using firearms to stop immigrants.

Since part of the agreement is secret in this case as well, I wonder whether the Commission is aware of its content, and whether it does not consider it necessary, in this specific case, to request explanations and details about this agreement.

It is an opportunity to remind the Libyan authorities of their ability to open fire on boats if there is a suspicion that they are carrying irregular immigrants, because if that were the case, such a provision would be ineffective.

From an economic standpoint, it is beneficial for Europe to deepen trade relations with neighboring countries experiencing strong growth. However, the EU has always pursued, at least in words, a trade policy towards third countries that takes into account social and humanitarian aspects.

We must therefore enforce these clauses with firm determination against Turkey, a country that is becoming increasingly Islamic and where the condition of women is gradually deteriorating, with more than
We have seen women killed in cases of domestic violence in 2009, a country where Christians live in fear of attacks by Islamic extremists.

In the report, Parliament encourages Turkey to take a leading role in promoting fair and open trade. One thing is certain: we must be concerned about the political leadership role that Turkey is trying to carve out for itself in the Arab world and its

The friendship Turkey is cultivating with Iran and terrorist groups like Hamas. However, if it must be a trade policy, so be it, but this must never become the Trojan horse to facilitate Turkey's entry into Europe.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, Commissioner, this measure aims to strengthen and streamline the European Union's pharmacovigilance system.
These are the ambitious goals set out in the McAvan reports, which amend Regulation 726 and Directive 2001 respectively.
This was made possible thanks to close and efficient collaboration between the Council and the European Parliament, and the relevant parliamentary committees.
we are discussing today a proposal aimed at improving the Community pharmacovigilance system and refining the European Union's extensive and decades-long work in this field.

Simplification, transparency and rationalisation can be considered the key points of these two reports, which propose measures aimed at ensuring the best possible protection of public health based on standards harmonised throughout Europe.

Reference is made, in fact, to a wide range of interventions ranging from a better definition of the roles and responsibilities of the main national and supranational stakeholders, to a new and more consciously active involvement of the patient, to whom the Commission is addressing itself.

The Commission recognizes a fundamental role of the actor in the system in strengthening the transparency of information regarding the safety of medicinal products, in simplifying the activities of communication, registration and evaluation of alleged negative side effects.
The current pharmacovigilance system needs to be improved, also thanks to closer collaboration at European, national and regional levels.
Effective participation at all three levels will indeed ensure a profitable exchange of information regarding the side effects of medications.
The new pharmacovigilance system will be able to ensure a high level of shared and secure information for the benefit of patients, national authorities and healthcare professionals.
The final work of this Parliament has just been completed here in Brussels.

Many representatives of municipalities and regions have discussed how to address the serious problems that affect the life of our cities, the old and new needs that concern workers, families, and small and large production companies.
The economic crisis that has befallen our societies has made it harder and more difficult for everyone to provide adequate responses to a new serious social issue.
In this context, I believe that everyone has understood that the cohesion policy has, on many occasions, been the only concrete tool available to the territories to attempt to provide answers.
Therefore, we can say that the cohesion policy has been an essential lever for the European integration process for all regions in recent years.
We are now in the process of redefining this policy for the post-2013 period, so we are at a turning point.
For this reason, it is vital to avoid certain risks.
The first fundamental one is that of its renationalization, which would be a serious step backwards.

Then, when constructing the funding budget, it is necessary to ensure that there is an adequate provision for both the weaker regions and, at the same time, the ability not to penalize the most competitive and advanced regions.
Finally, it is essential to simplify the procedures for those who have proven to be efficient and to make the ability to impose sanctions more binding for those who have not.
We expect the Commission to go in this direction.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the road towards a Europe tailored to women is still long and difficult.
The statistics are clear: the global crisis has hit the job market hard, putting a strain on female employment, which decreased by an additional 0.7 percentage points in 2008.

Despite the provocations on the topic of equal opportunities and employment that periodically fill the airwaves with propaganda laden with consensus, to this day no concrete measures have been adopted to guarantee women true fulfillment as workers and as mothers.
The Europe of the future needs to radically rethink its welfare model and not simply change the label periodically.

The directive that aligns maternity leave in Europe is therefore a good thing, but the decision to deal with the complementary and equally important issue of paternity leave in the same report, on the margins of this subject, is inefficient.

The greater integration of women is not only a moral value, but also a strategic goal for the sustainability of the much-publicized European social model, which continues to fail to convince me due to the lack of results.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, honourable colleagues, honourable colleagues, honourable colleagues, honourable colleagues, honourable colleagues, honourable colleagues, honourable colleagues, honourable colleagues, honourable colleagues.

I thank him for the work he has done with his usual punctuality, and for the quality of his proposals, which have received the favorable opinion, I would say unanimous, of the Committee on Development.
Based on what I will say, but especially on what my colleague Michel has done so far, I am convinced that the report can be voted on with a large majority.
But I now come to the report.
In the course of 2009, the European Commission presented a proposal to amend Regulation 1905, which establishes a financial instrument for development cooperation.
With this proposal, the Commission had asked Parliament to approve an amendment that would allow non-governmental organizations to benefit from tax advantages when operating in developing countries.
proposal accepted by us.
But the cooperation and development regulation also contains the implementing rules for the European Union's development policy.
These rules stipulate that when the Commission is to allocate funding, it must follow the comitology procedures.

This means that Parliament has the power to examine these funding proposals and, in the event that the Commission exceeds its authority, Parliament can then adopt resolutions to request the Commission to change the decisions in question.

Only from 2006 to the present day has the Parliament considered that in at least twelve cases the Commission had exceeded its implementing powers, but in only three of these cases has the Commission actually modified or withdrawn its proposal for a decision.
Following the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, the Committee on Development proposed to apply the procedure for delegated acts provided for in Article 290 of the Lisbon Treaty.
The adoption of these procedures would mean that, at least in the strategic funding decisions that the European Commission must adopt, Parliament would have a more significant role.
In fact, according to the Lisbon Treaty, in certain well-defined cases, Parliament can delegate to the Commission the power to make strategic decisions, but what could these decisions be?
In our opinion, the choice of countries to which the European Union should provide development aid

It is a choice that falls to the legislator, and then to which sectors should priority be given in funding: education, health, environmental protection, the capacity for good governance, the development of small businesses?
And how to ensure transparency in the management of development aid?
These are the choices and issues where the European Parliament should play a more important role than it has in the past.
This is where the legislator must provide precise guidance to the executive.
And this is precisely the direction in which, I believe, the demands of European citizens are ultimately heading.
I really hope for the greatest possible consensus on this report by Mr Mitchell.
The report was presented to the rapporteur.

Integrated maritime policy requires moving beyond the phase of good intentions and giving new impetus to a strategy that will act as a driver for growth and development in the European Union, making up for the enormous delays accumulated in preventing environmental disasters, combating climate change, and fighting pollution.
This very morning our colleague Pirillo reminded Parliament of yet another catastrophic event that occurred in recent days in the city of Paola, in Calabria.

The Commission must demonstrate its commitment by not only using governance tools, but also implementing specific legislative measures, drawing the necessary lessons from past mistakes, which were often due to an overly sectoral approach.
There is full awareness that this process is very complex, but we are in the midst of a difficult and challenging endeavor, which cannot tolerate a lack of attention and requires adequate investment.

governance mechanisms, involving both inter-institutional participation and international cooperation for regional basins, with the Mediterranean standing out due to the complexity of its jurisdiction.
It will therefore be essential to understand the management of the Mediterranean basin as a common heritage to all the coastal states, based on the principle of the

On the other hand, the increasingly widespread practice of unilaterally declaring exclusive economic zones or similar in the Mediterranean Sea, besides not being in line with the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, would undermine the idea of effective and shared governance.

I would like to remind you in this regard that just a month ago this interpretation by Libya led to an actual armed assault on a European fishing boat, and it would be wrong to claim that this is purely an Italian-Libyan issue.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, I thank Mrs Meissner for the report on the integrated maritime policy, I agree with the rapporteur on the need to strengthen maritime transport and shipbuilding and to protect coastal regions, as well as to promote innovation and research activities.
Today, maritime transport plays a fundamental role in the commercial sector.
For this reason, cooperation should be encouraged between small and large ports that face the same sea basin and can facilitate a more fluid commercial exchange.
Moreover, to ensure intermodality, investment is needed in port and hinterland infrastructure, especially in ports that can be connected to European corridors.
Finally, I believe it is important not to overlook another issue, namely that of port security.

There needs to be a homogenization of all security measures within all European ports, in order to better protect maritime transport and prevent unfair competition at the expense of those ports that, in order to guarantee greater security, must incur higher expenses.
