Mr President, honourable colleagues, 30 years ago Morocco denied for many years that there was a war with the Sahrawi people, today it is denying that there is a disproportionate repression against the same people.
Yet in Western Sahara there are dead and wounded from a population that claims only the right to live in freedom in their own land.
Morocco has essentially closed its borders to anyone who might witness these events.
No information and no deputies.
A French MP and our colleague Mayer were denied access.
Europe watches passively.
There is no sign in the Commission's communication that makes us subordinate to UN mediation, which continues to fail as it has for the past thirty years.
There is no statement from Mrs. Ashton, who is responsible for foreign policy.
A response is needed in the form of a parliamentary resolution.
A response is needed with regard to Morocco, by halting all initiatives on trade agreements, starting with the renewal of the fisheries agreements.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, my speech is not intended to be the usual eurosceptic rhetorical exercise, but an impulse for the EU to start focusing more on content than on packaging and to abandon propaganda in favour of concreteness.
Having failed with the Lisbon strategy, Europe has come up with the new EU 2020 slogan, but in reality it has not provided any innovative solutions to employment problems.

The data confirms it: 9.6% unemployment rate in Europe, 20.2% for youth. In Italy, the third largest net contributor to the EU budget, the situation for young people is even more dramatic, with 25.9% of young people without a job.

In the Europe I would like to see, there is no waste of resources in promotional campaigns, but rather efficient investments so that the educational offerings prepare professionals for the sectors of the internal market, where there are concrete employment opportunities.
I conclude by reiterating the importance of investing in professional training, a symbol of the excellence of our regions.
The world of craftsmanship offers a potential for employment and a unique wealth of knowledge, to which the task of supporting the competitiveness of the European system must be entrusted.

Mr President, Commissioner, Madam President of the Council, the European will to set ambitious goals in view of the next conference on climate change is certainly a commitment to be pursued with tenacity and with the awareness that the results will condition the future of our planet.
But it is precisely for this reason, dear colleagues, that we must be realistic and more cautious in our expectations.

The international negotiations leading up to the Cancun Conference, as far as we know, have not only failed to make appreciable progress towards a global agreement, but have also confirmed the distrust and resistance to the commitments made in Copenhagen.
China has already been mentioned, but I would like to mention it here as well.
China, for example, is allowing its emissions to increase by 5 billion tons of CO2 by 2020, with consequences that could be offset
And perhaps not even that, but an attempt at compensation with only a 100% reduction in European industrial emissions by the same year, by 2020.

This fact not only makes the proposal for an unconditional 30% reduction, which we strongly oppose, unfeasible, but also leads many independent observers to hypothesize a significant increase in global emissions by that date.

In this contradictory situation, it would be at the very least risky and even demagogic to hypothesize numbers and outline appealing but unrealistic scenarios, where unknowns inevitably impact the cost dimension.

The hope is that the European Union will bring a shared, realistic and sustainable proposal to Cancun, because an agreement that delivers concrete and perceptible results is always preferable to a long-term agreement.

expectations inevitably doomed to failure and increasingly discrediting in the eyes of international public opinion, this would indeed be a difficult damage to repair, the efforts of governments on major environmental issues.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, I have only one regret in this Chamber tonight that we are discussing the Sahrawi only because the Moroccans have invaded the Tent City outside El Aaiun and this is a regret for democracy in this Parliament.
Parliament should have matured the will to discuss this issue that has been festering on international tables for thirty years.
This is the most significant political fact.
We were forced by acts of violence, not because we autonomously decided to ensure human rights.
What is it if not respect for human rights, the fact that there should be a referendum on self-determination there?
It is precisely because Morocco is our friend, because Morocco is the strong point of our relations. We must demand forcefully, with all the necessary actions, that there be an irrefutable will.
We must try to build the conditions so that the meticulous and closed mission, Mr. President, does not alone build the conditions for a referendum that is constantly postponed.
We must try to use all the means at the disposal of the European Union to influence this event and to ensure that the referendum does justice to the thirty years of suffering of a people.
Mr President, quite apart from this issue, I wanted to raise a problem with the Presidency.
I believe that some people still do not fully understand the role of the European Parliament after the Treaty of Lisbon.

Commissioner Callas for transport is repeatedly refusing to meet with the Sky and Space board to discuss the SESAR project, which is of interest to everyone from an economic, environmental, and safety perspective, and I am forced to raise this fundamental issue here.
I call on the Presidency to invite Commissioner Kallas to the Chamber and to explain what programme he intends to pursue in this extremely sensitive and important sector for the European Parliament.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the report under discussion certainly contains some positive elements: the general approach is that of simplifying procedures and streamlining bureaucratic steps for workers from third countries with a regular residence permit in a Member State.

However, just as a point of reflection, I would like to remind you that today in Europe tens of millions of citizens, including many young people, are without work due to the structural shortcomings of the European production system and the effects of a crisis that shows no sign of ending.

Even before taking care of citizens from third countries who reside in our countries, Europe should primarily focus on implementing economic, political, and social measures that help, first and foremost, our citizens to find or regain employment.
If Europe can provide jobs for its citizens, it will create solid social foundations to properly manage migratory flows from outside.
The watchword must be, first and foremost, to make Europe grow on its own legs and with its own strength.
And then there are the problems for our countries.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, to date, access to employment is regulated only for certain specific categories of third-country nationals.
In fact, not everyone benefits from the general principle of equal treatment in access to employment.

In this context, the European Union must take action to ensure fair treatment for both third-country nationals who reside legally within the Member States and beneficiaries of refugee status or persons in need of international protection, in accordance with Directive 83 of 29 April 2004.

It is necessary to prevent a growing demand, for example, for seasonal workers just because they are paid less or because they have different, lower costs compared to a European citizen recruited for the same job.

For example, we must avoid the risk that many multinationals will move their headquarters to countries like Morocco or Turkey and send their employees to work in European branches because it is cheaper.
For reasons of social justice, ensuring the same treatment of European citizens in terms of remuneration, working conditions, and social security is fundamental.
For this reason, I believe it is right that seasonal workers, posted workers, refugees and self-employed workers should be included in this directive.
Drawing distinctions will become extremely dangerous.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, according to estimates by international organisations and police forces, human trafficking is now the second most profitable source of income for organised crime worldwide, after drug trafficking.
It is estimated that around 30 million people are victims of organ trafficking, prostitution, and forced labor.

This means that, first and foremost, the fight against this criminal phenomenon of vast proportions is a battle for the safety of our citizens, against illegal immigration, against crime that generates more crime.
Faced with a phenomenon of this magnitude, Europe must rightly implement drastic measures against those who exploit human beings in various forms.
For this reason, in the fight against this phenomenon, cooperation between member countries and police forces is necessary, but above all, the certainty of punishment for traffickers is essential.

They are not exploited because in their countries of origin they do not find decent living conditions, they live in poverty and despair and are ready to do anything to leave their land in search of the promise of a better life that will never materialize.

Europe, then, in addition to crime prevention and protection of trafficking victims, must commit itself more and with greater diligence so that these people can find acceptable living conditions in their own countries.
We must help them at home, this must be the guiding principle of European political action, so that our efforts are directed not only at repression but also at prevention.
It's a bit too much.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, as Vice-Chairman of the Committee on Development, I am concerned with the problems of many countries, especially in the African region, where human rights are regularly violated, trampled underfoot, if not sometimes even forgotten.

I returned just last Sunday from an official mission to the Democratic Republic of Congo, where, in addition to the institutional meetings in Rito, I wanted to meet with representatives of the NGOs operating in the country and visit some of the centers where they work.
I met the victims in a country where rape is conceived as a weapon of war, where armed groups continue to attack women and children.
repeatedly commit mass rapes and other systematic crimes against civilian society, especially against women, the elderly, and children.
I wanted to mention the example of the Democratic Republic of Congo because it was a recent experience of mine, as I was saying, a very recent one.
But the appeal I want to make is aimed generally at the need for a strong and continuous condemnation of the brutal violations of women's rights.
The international community must significantly increase funding for initiatives to protect women and address other forms of violence.
violence, including genital mutilation, is a serious violation of women's human rights and physical integrity.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the European Heritage Label is of fundamental importance for a continent that contains the majority of UNESCO sites and which, due to its significance, is important.
Finally, it highlights those natural, archaeological, urban and cultural sites that have played an important role in the history, culture and integration of the European Union.
The approval of the label is an important step for the cohesion process of the Union and is also educational and formative for cultural dialogue.
It can also be noted that this choice bodes well for the new generations, who will increasingly have a shared vision of the European heritage that can accumulate historically and culturally.

Thank you for the rapporteur's efforts and I extend my warmest congratulations for the negotiations conducted with the Commission for the effective success of this initiative, so important for the future of environmental preservation.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer's, are a health priority for the European Union.
The disease in question has serious implications, not just for the health of those who suffer from it.
But the costs that must be borne for direct and informal care are indeed high.
Alzheimer's disease, in fact, not only affects the people who are afflicted by it, but also involves all those who care for the patients themselves.

A European response to the problem is therefore necessary, a global coordination between the Member States, a synergy of concerted actions that primarily concern the scientific and research field and that address the

strengthening prevention, diagnosis, and improvement of available treatments, including innovative ones, as well as the dissemination of information among states on the results achieved within their own incremental, citizen-level knowledge of the disease.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the situation is that Campania, in particular the city of Naples, is now universally and unfortunately known throughout the world, and the European Union has had to deal with the issue on several occasions.

Faced with this now paradoxical third-world situation, I therefore ask the Commission what consequences Italy will face from the point of view of Community law and what economic sanctions will possibly be imposed on Italy if the waste crisis in the countryside does not find a definitive solution in the short term.

I also ask whether the Commission can provide detailed data on the European funds that have so far been managed by the Campania region for the creation of an integrated waste collection and disposal system.
You see, Commissioner, usually when we talk about an emergency, we are talking about dramatic, extreme situations, which however find a solution within a reasonable timeframe.
When a so-called emergency lasts for more than 15 years, obviously something is not working.
In recent years, the Italian government has tried to do everything possible to resolve the long-standing issue of waste collection and disposal.
The blame primarily lies with the local, Campania authorities and their total inability or lack of willingness to work towards finding a solution.

It is clear and absolutely beyond any doubt that the conditions in which Naples and Campania find themselves are due to the negligence that has characterized the management of the waste cycle by the municipality, province, and regions for many years.
If proper waste sorting is not carried out, which is the first essential element of a functioning waste management plan, it cannot be the fault of the central government.

If the Italian government had to send in the army a few weeks ago, and other times before that, to replace hundreds of street cleaners who suddenly and simultaneously fell ill, it obviously cannot be the fault of the central government.

If the emergency has hit Naples, while in the rest of Italy things are going very differently, for example in my region, Veneto, where fruit harvesting has been done for years without problems and with a very high cycle rate, it means that the responsibilities for the emergency fall on

on Campania's politics and local administrators, and especially on the heavy collusion with organized crime, which has always sought and obtained enormous profits from the waste business, thanks to the infiltration of the Camorra into politics and local administrations.
After the lies of the Berlusconi government, which took office in 2008 telling Italians that the waste problem had been solved, the European Union is doing the right thing.
to block funds to Italy until an eco-friendly waste cycle is presented that is based on waste recycling and composting.

President Caldoro's plan is certainly not the one that once again relies on uncontrolled landfills, such as those in Chiaiano, Taverna del Re, and Terzigno, even within the Vesuvius National Park, nor on incinerators that produce death, cancer, or a true health emergency.

Public money in the countryside, during the environmental emergency of these thirteen years, has consolidated the criminal relationships between politics, both left and right, entrepreneurs, and the Camorra.

And environmental issues are resolved by criminalizing dissent, by criminalizing local communities, families, and the territory, as the Italian government has done by using the malganello to suppress those who defend nature and the territory.

An international refugee is a political refugee who, fearing persecution for reasons of race, religion, nationality, social membership or for his political opinions, finds himself outside the country of which he is a citizen.
Cesare Battisti is not a political persecuted person.

Despite the cover provided for years by France, we are talking about a multi-murdering criminal, perpetrator or instigator of four murders, who has hidden behind the pretext of political struggle to escape life imprisonment.
It is disgraceful for a great country like Brazil to deny the extradition of a unrepentant criminal, recognizing him as a political refugee.
Italian authorities and, above all, the victims' families demand that this criminal be brought to justice.
Faced with President Lula's high-handedness in banning extradition, the EU cannot leave the Italian government alone.

Europe has and must use all the diplomatic tools at its disposal to ensure that Italy obtains the extradition of Battisti, even at the cost of threatening to suspend cooperation agreements with Brasilia.
to provide concrete support to the Tunisian people and its transitional government, to relaunch a Euro-Mediterranean dialogue that has been greatly neglected in recent years.
The explosion of anger among the youth and the poor in the Maghreb and Egypt stems from the unequal distribution of wealth and the restrictions on the exercise of fundamental freedoms.

North Africa is ablaze, demanding more democracy, more economy, more participation, more jobs, and looks with astonishment at the old European continent, immobile and incapable of grasping the social transformations that have taken place in that area and of developing real policies of progress and peace.
Let Europe pay more attention to human rights and democracy, foster more dialogue, more collaboration, and more real economic interventions.
Europe must open its doors and its heart to North Africa in order to make the Mediterranean a sea of peace.
Enough with the rejection of immigrants and the violent collaboration of countries like Libya. Instead, we need more investment, more hospitality, more aid, and more Euro-Mediterranean policy.
History demands it.
The resolution approved today by a majority on the waste emergency in Campania is a very important signal.
The Campania emergency becomes a European emergency and it is a decision in favor of the citizens of Campania.
No to the allocation of funds that simply consolidate corrupt politicians, unscrupulous entrepreneurs, and the Camorra; yes to European money if a credible plan is presented, a credible plan.
An environmentally compatible waste management plan, no to uncontrolled dumping in national parks, no to incinerators that produce dioxin, but yes to recycling and environmentally compatible forms.
And it also says no to the criminalization of dissent by local communities, therefore yes to legality.

It is an important turning point, a warning to the Berlusconi government and to the regional government led by Caldoro, who until now have only talked and consolidated the cliques and the mafia bourgeoisie.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the problem of falsified medicines is having an increasingly widespread impact at international and Community level, both due to the increase in the number of cases and the improvement in their sophistication.
It is to these challenges that Mr. Mathias's report seeks to respond, the result of long and laborious negotiations.
The report, which we supported, established a regulatory framework that, starting from more precise and detailed definitions, took into account the needs of each country.
We must address all the players, moments, and resignations in the pharmaceutical supply chain, security, traceability, obligations for the distribution chain, and achieve a good compromise.
These are some of the aspects on which it is necessary to work in order to achieve the first objective of establishing stricter rules, in order to prevent the entry of new workers.
of counterfeit medicines, leading to a positive and more comprehensive regulatory framework capable of safeguarding the health of citizens, protecting them from the risk of serious consequences.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, Egypt, from the virtual square on Facebook to the real one, with millions of people demanding a fairer distribution of wealth, more justice, protesting against corruption.
From the transition of soldiers and charlatans, we must move on to real democracy: a new constitution, new elections, abolition of the death penalty, more humane prisons, social rights and freedoms.
It will be difficult.
Lurking are those who, in the name of an idea, think they can use any means.
We want to believe in the wonderful Egyptian people, who have never experienced democracy.

We want a secular democracy, with a clear separation between religious and political power, a democracy that integrates minorities and realizes true rights, public health, social security, and employment.
Europe should support this path, but invest resources that can foster the true development of Egypt: no more dictatorships, no more misery, no more poverty.
Mr President, Commissioner, I believe that with this measure, the issues related to the Mediterranean have entered an even more compelling phase than the actions we have taken so far.
I believe that the act we are enshrining today is much more important than what is in the Community regulation of 2006.

I think this also addresses some limitations of that regulation, which, being unilateral, has left large sectors of the fishing industry often supporting the idea that Europe does its part, but other coastal countries do not.
I think it is strategic for us to address the topic in this dimension and with these characteristics.
The work carried out by my colleague Rivellini, which I fully support, deserves a formal expression of thanks in this context.
Nevertheless, I have the distinct feeling that the fact that we are unable to resolve this issue at first reading and will proceed to a second reading
The report, especially on the interpretation of Article 28 of this regulation, raises a question; on this occasion, Parliament sided with the Commission.

Parliament essentially says that it is good that these delegated acts are the responsibility of the Commission, and there is some resistance from the Council; moreover, today's absence is also a significant one.
But this act ensures that the idea is ripe in Parliament that maintaining biodiversity, maintaining the fish stocks of this important sea is also the future of fishermen.
That being said, I think that the phase we are facing must bring back the idea of codecision to the forefront.
These delegated acts have a reason for being delegated and therefore conferred today to the Commission, but international agreements must maintain Parliament's role intact when these occur.
Mr President, Commissioner, I believe we have two problems in this matter: one of method and one of substance.

The methodological issue is that we are proceeding through a procedural device for which we are grateful to Mr Fraga, namely the oral question, in order to discuss something that, following the Treaty of Lisbon, should instead be a right of this Parliament.
I think this practice must end and we cannot resort to a strategy to accompany a codecision process.
Codecision is such when it is cultivated in the phases in which it matures.
Today we are having this debate, the treaty is ending, it will go ahead and we will say yes or no in the end.
Well, this method needs to be reconverted.

On the substance, however, I just wanted to emphasize, as I agree with many things said by my colleagues, the measurement of the effects of fisheries agreements, so that they are not just mere commercial agreements through which we go to buy cephalopods for one euro per kilogram in Mauritania.

They must be able to measure both sustainability, but above all the impact on the economy of that country, understand how many employees are changing, understand what rate of innovation exists for artisanal fishing, understand the use of these resources.
It is not just a simple trade exchange, but a fisheries agreement with all its implications.
The vote in favour of Mr Rivasi's report is the result of an assessment of the management of H1N1 influenza.
2001 which is 2009 which aims to establish general guidelines for conduct that would be valid in any future global health emergencies.
The report, following a long and positive phase of revision, makes cooperation, independence and transparency its main pillars.
It aspires to greater and better cooperation between the health authorities of the Member States and European institutions, so that a harmonised and coordinated risk management can be developed.
The objectives are to demonstrate the strategy of the Member States regarding national influenza management plans, including vaccine stocks, and to publish the names of individuals.
expert institutes consulted by European health authorities and an efficient, trust-based relationship with the media responsible for disseminating public health messages.
That is why it received our favorable vote.

Mr President, honourable Members, to date, the recommendations adopted by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean have been incorporated into Community legislation on a provisional basis, through annual regulations on fishing opportunities.
These concern conservation measures, management, exploitation, control and marketing for fishery and aquaculture products in the Mediterranean.
The permanent nature of these recommendations, however, requires a more stable legal instrument for their incorporation into Community law.
It is therefore appropriate to receive the recommendations in question through a single legislative act, to which future recommendations can be added.
Today we have done this and it will improve legal certainty, while also being an important step towards simplification.
At this point, the contracting parties of the CGMPM are required to ensure full implementation of the agreed measures starting from the date set.

A timely transposition was therefore necessary in order to make these international measures directly applicable to natural or legal persons at Community level and to ensure legal certainty in this area.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, I believe that the approval of my colleague Podima's report represents a significant step forward for a more balanced, more advanced, and stronger economic and fiscal policy in the European arena.

It is now clear to everyone that Europe, as a coordination between the twenty-seven countries, urgently needs to equip itself with economic and financial instruments capable of governing the economy rather than merely being governed by it.
For this reason, the proposal for a financial transaction tax has received a great deal of attention, sparked a major debate, and generated a lot of discussion.

The fact that the majority of this Parliament voted for this rule is an important and significant event, because for the first time, things were not left to chance, and instead, a step forward was taken.
I hope that the Commission and the Council continue along this path.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, I welcome the reports on equality between men and women and on female poverty in Europe and I am pleased that they have been discussed today, on the centenary of International Women's Day.

Despite Directive 2002 on equal treatment between men and women as regards access to employment, vocational training and promotion, and working conditions, further efforts are still needed to achieve proper implementation.

Suffice it to say that, despite the level of female education having increased significantly in recent years and the number of female graduates now exceeding that of male graduates, women remain concentrated in traditionally female and often less remunerative sectors, and hold fewer positions of responsibility in all spheres of society.

The lack of access to care services for dependent persons, such as children, disabled persons and the elderly, to adequate leave schemes and to flexible working arrangements prevents women from working.

I would like to conclude by remembering the women around the world who are fighting for the most basic rights, and I would like our Assembly to express solidarity with the Iranian feminist associations that are taking to the streets today, inviting women to demonstrate without the hijab.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, to all the colleagues who have spoken, I say that we are finally talking again and I hope that we will soon return to action with specific choices of economic policy and common industrial policy.
Thanks to the Lange report, the excellent work done by my colleague, and the communication from President Tajani.

This choice means a few important things: first, the relaunch and recovery of the European economy and the maintenance of employment also lie, perhaps above all, in the recovery and support of everything that is currently underway.

A manufacturing sector, both in the most advanced sectors and in the traditional ones, because there is a frontier there that is still possible to tackle and that was not so obvious until a short time ago.

Secondly, the recovery of industrial sectors in Europe also means that our competitiveness is not at stake in the finance and service sectors, but still here, and it is not too late to do so, we can set a challenge for Europe to regain competitiveness with the rest of the world in industrial sectors.

The third point is that the new industrial policy focuses on factors rather than sectors, focusing on the factors and tools that can truly promote new businesses and new capacity for resilience and updating.

So I believe it is important to highlight them, as has been done, these new factors on which credit must be acted. We are calling for new initiatives, in addition to those already announced by the Commissioner on the subject of credit, raw materials, and energy costs.
innovation, research, the need to enhance Europe's capacity to transfer the results of research and innovation into businesses, new products, and new production methods and organization.

We have to enhance a very distinctive fabric in our Europe, in some countries particularly that of SMEs, that of the quality of companies, the quality of products, in short, the distinctiveness of industry in Europe.
I believe we should rediscover, let's say, these manufacturing traditions, these manufacturing roots in many countries, in order to renew and change them.
Finally, the theme of the territory, which is very important.
European policies are successful if they intersect and find a territory capable of addressing them.
So thank you to Lange and we hope for excellent collaboration with the Commission to achieve concrete results in a short time.
Many milestones have been achieved, but some battles have yet to begin.
Today the urgency concerns women from other cultures living in Europe and the world, in contexts where it is difficult for them to claim minimum standards of dignity and humanity.

We cannot celebrate this festival without placing the issue of women in the Arab Muslim world at the center, otherwise we continue to ignore a problem that today concerns them, but soon will become ours too.
We cannot ignore the emergency figures that are growing year by year, even in Europe, in our cities, in the schools where our children grow up.
Cases of violence of all kinds that Muslim women suffer within their own families have been on the rise for some time.

This is why I have been asking for some time, and I ask again today, that Europe implement targeted policies against the spread of Islamic radicalism, forced marriages, honor killings, female genital mutilation, and domestic violence.
We women, European men, must fight for those women who live in Europe, but not only there, who have no voice and are oppressed by the monster of Islamic intellectualism.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, I voted in favour of the resolution on Turkey because the constitutional reform that took place on 12 September last was unanimously recognised as an important step taken by Turkey towards Europe.
Of course, there are still many steps to be taken, and I express my concern about the numerous arrests of journalists.

It is worth noting that Turkey is the European Union's seventh largest trading partner and that the European Union is Turkey's main trading partner, and that trade, correctly interpreted for centuries, has fostered the interpenetration and peaceful understanding of peoples.

I therefore welcome the significant progress made in boosting connections between the European Union and Turkey, particularly those via the motorways of the sea crossing the northern Adriatic and northern Tyrrhenian Sea.
On which a flow of over 250 t of RANUY now moves in both directions, in connection with an important railway and truck connection from the port to inland European destinations.
it has been possible to eliminate a significant amount of truck traffic on the road and I hope that this trend will continue.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, with today's vote we have given a further boost to the definitive solution of this problem, but we have not voted for the best possible solution.

In fact, I would like to point out that the more than 300 amendments tabled in the report have been transformed into 38 compromise amendments, all of which have been adopted, and which aim to better define the priority sectors of the strategy, that is, the objectives of this strategy.

The Commission, with the permanent task force, will ensure the collection and dissemination of statistical data and best practices, and Member States should appoint an official, hopefully of high government level, who serves as a contact point for the implementation of the strategy.
But we could have been even more incisive and less hypocritical if in the report we had focused on the obligations and duties that the Roma community should still respect in the host countries.
This is my hope, that solutions will be found soon that allow for better coexistence of this community in all member states.
Lampedusa has been invaded by tens of thousands of North Africans that the island could never, ever, accommodate.
Italy has been targeted by hundreds of clandestine boats for weeks.
If we do not all react together, if the EU does not react, the wave of migration of people on the run will continue.
The illegal immigrants who arrived in recent months must be sent home, there is no alternative.
But the Italian government, beyond a few words of solidarity, has been left alone to manage this biblical exodus of unpredictable dimensions. Where is Europe?
Up until now, Brussels has been overly lenient, it has behaved shamefully, and my fellow citizens can no longer tolerate it.
Europe has left Italy alone to face an unprecedented emergency.

However, Europe must not only help Italy with the repatriation of illegal immigrants, but also support the Italian government's efforts to prevent thousands and thousands of people from continuing to leave, especially from Tunisia.

This, however, applies to Libyan refugees, for whom Europe must stand by Italy in the operations of identification and logistical management, but above all must commit to ensuring that refugees are hosted in all Member States.
The reception of those fleeing from war cannot fall solely on Italy.
It's time to stop talking.
The European Union, if it exists, must take action.
We cannot tolerate Italy being filled with illegal immigrants while France rejects them with disgraceful methods.
Illegal immigrants must be sent back home, while all member states must commit themselves now to welcoming Libyan refugees.
The issue of forecasting adequate financial resources to ensure the decommissioning of nuclear power plants is a problem that has already been addressed by the European Commission.
European Union legislation on nuclear safety is currently of great relevance, in light of recent international events and the consequent decisions of the Union's governments on this matter.

Mr Marinescu's work, which we have supported, addresses the specific cases of certain countries which, at the time of their accession, took on particular obligations regarding the decommissioning of nuclear plants and which received special support from the European Union for this very activity.
Beyond specific cases, this issue will require the establishment of effective verification and examination controls for nuclear power plants located within the territory of the Union.
The number of reactors that are expected to be decommissioned in the near future within the Community territory appears to be high.
It will therefore be essential to ensure guarantee mechanisms, especially in these cases, for the allocation of adequate financial resources necessary to meet both ordinary and extraordinary needs.
I would also like to thank the rapporteur for his report.
The report takes into account the recent changes in control and communication systems.
This also reveals a picture of great regional diversity, particularly among the states, in the reporting of irregularities and fraud.

The report repeatedly points out the oddity of the low levels of fraud and irregularities reported by various countries in relation to agricultural expenditure, structural funds, and pre-accession funds.
Here, it is truly necessary to clarify the statistical data that has been provided.
The situation is then exacerbated by the well-known ineffectiveness of recovery efforts.
However, one thing is clear and confirms a long-term trend.

The fight for legality and transparency in the spending of European resources, such as combating tax evasion and avoidance, still cannot count on the full cooperation of the states, governments, and European institutions.

In this sense, I believe the suggestions for a revision of the EU regulations on public procurement and the need for what I call a European public registry of beneficiaries of EU funds are appropriate.
I thank the speakers and also Commissioner Barnier for his great willingness to cooperate with Parliament.
We support an idea of the internal market that is capable of understanding and meeting social expectations and the implications that the social dimension entails.
It is not a utopia, it is realism and also modernity.

It is indeed this vision that makes the market itself stronger, because the sole economic element, economicism in essence, the reduction of the market to economicism, has demonstrated that all of this does not solve either the problems of growth or those of cohesion.
In short, it is a matter of fully and presently realizing the European idea of a social and market economy.
This is present in today's texts.
There is recognition of social enterprises, cooperatives, their role, mutual societies, foundations, 10% of European businesses and a large part of our employment.
they are real companies, demonstrating economic pluralism and business pluralism.

They work with capital but not for capital, and they want to create jobs, welfare, quality, and social innovation, and demonstrate that these values must and can be part of the internal market in Europe.

Mr President, Beijing's justification that the artist Huey Huey was arrested for economic crimes does not convince us, nor does it convince us that such harassment is being carried out against a free and dissident artist.
It is not convincing, because this arrest is part of hundreds of arrests of opponents and the systematic repression of any dissent.

In the days when Arab uprisings are exploding, our thoughts go to the image of cruel violence in Tien Amen Square against the young Chinese people who were demanding, as they are doing today with the Jasmine Revolution, freedom and democracy.
China has opened up to the West economically, but without linking production to environmental protection and labor safety, and it fails to make any concessions to democracy and pluralism.
This is not interference in China's internal affairs, as Beijing claims, but the appeal of men and women, movements, and parties who intend to build a world free from intolerance on every continent.
The government in Beijing should look at what is happening in the world to understand that if it does not change, it will be the events of history and the Chinese citizens that will change China.
Jobs lost despite several million euros invested in support policies.

This is the sobering assessment of the impact on SMEs of the triumphant Lisbon I project and the carbon copy Europe 2020 strategy, on which it is even being decided to concentrate the resources of the next multiannual financial framework 2014.

I can only reiterate what thousands of European citizens and taxpayers are asking themselves: what is the point of Europe if it is unable to solve the continent's economic problems, cannot speak with a single voice on foreign policy, and squanders money?
I hope that what I have said several times will come true, as Commissioner Tajani has also stated.
I hope that the revision of the SME code will truly be able to simplify bureaucracy, ensure access and recovery of credit, and facilitate networking.
The directive on late payment represents a concrete and real achievement, but it is the result of political will rather than Euro-propaganda.

If the costs of yet another strategy will only fund more talk, I call on the European institutions to make amends to the dozens of small entrepreneurs in my region, Veneto, who have taken their own lives before seeing their small business fail.

Mr President, while Europe pretends nothing is happening, Europol's 2011 report on organised crime states that with the entry of Romania and Bulgaria into Schengen, powerful Turkish, Russian and Albanian criminal organisations will be able to expand their activities throughout Europe.
Furthermore, I quote verbatim: illegal immigration from Turkey will spread to the Bulgarian coast, and drug and human trafficking will increase, controlled by Turkish-Albanian criminals.

Still on the subject of human trafficking, Romania and Bulgaria's entry into Schengen could provide Bulgarian criminals and new Roma communities with new opportunities to increase their already substantial trafficking operations to the rest of Europe.
In the end, an increase in illegal immigration from Turkey and in drug and human trafficking, less security for European citizens.
Europe wants to do organized crime a big favor.
The Northern League party is and will always be opposed to this kind of reckless decision.
Those who vote in favor of this report tomorrow will bear the responsibility for a vote that will open a highway to organized crime leading straight to the heart of Europe.
Thanks to the Amsterdam Treaty, environmental policy and sustainability policy have gained greater relevance and the report has been welcomed.
The focus was on the integration between economic and environmental policy and on the inclusion of environmental issues in policies and other sectors.

Key areas include climate change, sustainable transport, nature, biodiversity, health and the environment, as well as the use of natural resources and waste management, and the international dimension of sustainable development.
In June 2006, the European Council, in its conclusions, invited the Union and its Member States to extend national accounts to the key aspects of sustainable development.
National accounts must therefore be supplemented by an integrated economic and environmental accounting system, capable of providing fully consistent data.
I voted in favour of this proposed regulation because it creates new uses for national accounting data and for environmental statistics and for other statistical areas.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, my vote in favour of the Garriga report on the forthcoming financial perspectives of the Union stems from the belief that it is precisely in times of greatest crisis that evolution can occur.

For the so-called European spirit to be decisive, it is essential to insist on and prevail on the indispensability of providing credible instruments, starting with an adequate financial endowment for the Union.
Therefore, the request for an additional 5% for the next budget is a fair and necessary request, perhaps not sufficient, but indispensable for providing answers to the major issues before us.
We need to address real problems, such as stronger cohesion between regions, greater capacity for research and innovation, and a stronger ability to generate growth and provide employment.

If the conditions are right, none of these problems will find a sufficient answer, starting with the introduction of this intermediate category in cohesion policy, which only makes sense if it does not harm the other existing categories.
That is why I voted in favour and I hope that the Commission and the Council will follow the recommendations in this report.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the new Hungarian Constitution reduces the scope for intervention by supervisory bodies such as the Constitutional Court and increases the powers of the executive, thus calling into question the normal balance of power.
Social rights are being stripped away, the state provides subsidies to those in need only if they agree to perform public works.
Finally, the right to self-defense is enshrined, allowing people to possess weapons at home even without a license.
The right to abortion is prohibited and strongly discriminatory rules are introduced against homosexuals.
All of this is contrary to Directive No. 78, which establishes a general framework for combating discrimination.

I therefore ask the Commissioner how she intends to intervene, considering that the fundamental rights of the new Hungarian Constitution are poorly compatible with those of the European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, we are about to vote on a strategic document of great importance that provides a solid framework for the negotiation on the financial perspectives for the period after 2013.

Starting from the demand for consistency between objectives and instruments, between the new role that European institutions are called to play after Lisbon and in the face of the recession, and the resources that we collectively decide to invest.
This consistency also implies a serious response to the demand for innovation that emerges from public opinion, from the recipients of EU policies, and from European social and productive forces.
We did it for cohesion, a crucial chapter in deciding what we want and what the European Union will be in the coming years.
It is said that cohesion is today a vital component of the European project, an important asset for all to safeguard, protect, and renew.

Particularly critical on this front is the effort made regarding the hypothesis of introducing an intermediate category of regions, especially because in many cases the years of recession that we have behind us have

We have narrowed the internal disparities, making efficient and adequate support for the less developed regions of Europe even more important, fighting waste and making the development policy visible.
And yet I believe that the challenge of intermediate categories with the safeguard clause is a challenge we must accept in order to open a new phase in European politics.
of cohesion in Europe and also to underpin the cohesion policy with the more balanced, more sustainable development that we want to ensure for Europe in the coming years.
I too would like to join in thanking Mr Langen and the other colleagues with whom we have worked to put together this complex report.
I think what Mrs von der Leyen has pointed out is particularly important.
Langen, when he said that we want to maintain the scope, the field of application of this regulation, staying true to what was the mandate of the G20 in Pittsburgh in 2009.
The fundamental goal is to bring the majority of over-the-counter derivatives onto regulated platforms to avoid continuing to be exposed to a high degree of
When you get to the point, as has happened, of exchanging and securing 400 million dollars without collateral, that is, without adequate reserves, you understand what risks we are running.

Having said that, however, I would also like to mention two problems: the first problem is the relationship with the Council, the second problem is the organic nature of the proposal for the reform of the financial markets that we must push forward.

I raise the first problem regarding the Council, and I say this very clearly: the feeling is all too often that the Council represents an obstacle to making swift and effective progress on the reform of financial markets.
I hope that the new Presidency will take charge of this problem, because on this occasion too we must take it into account
Account should be taken of the extended timeframes, which are largely due to the positions, difficulties, and conflicts that arise within the Council.
It is a problem that also concerns the procedure we want to follow.
The second issue is the organic and specific nature of the measures.
It's not just the measure on OTCs, there's also the measure on short selling and other things.

I want to highlight two points: the specific issue of the commodities market, a particular market that requires specific anti-speculative measures, and the problem of local authorities' exposure to derivatives in EU countries.
I think these are issues that Parliament must address.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the Fukushima incident continues to produce very serious consequences, with the loss of sea and radioactive water 6 times higher than the legal limits.
The risk of food products being contaminated is high.
Europe has established very strict controls, but this applies exclusively to fresh produce.
No protective regulations have been issued for processed products, particularly for canned fish.
We import 370 tons of canned tuna and the main suppliers are the countries of Southeast Asia, which import fish from Japan.
This means that canned fish imported into Europe could contain Japanese fish.
It is crucial and urgent to provide precise information about the place of origin.
Today, in fact, consumers know where the box was produced, but not the place where the fish was caught.

The Commission has recently acknowledged this and plans to address this gap with the reform of the common fisheries policy, which, however, will not come into effect for another two years, just as the Sommer report under discussion in this plenary will not be effective for another three years.
We must not create alarmist situations, but consumers have the right to urgent and transparent information.
The Commission must intervene as soon as possible.
Mr. President Tusk, your speech gives us hope, and we hope that the Polish Presidency will contribute to the fight against the Europe of the selfish.
that is a contribution in favor of Europe that truly thinks of itself as an integrated entity with a common destiny.
But as you rightly said in your speech, a Presidency has concrete problems to face and solve.
In this short time, I want to point out two crucial issues on the economic and financial crisis front.
First issue: the reform of financial markets.
It is not a technical problem, it is a major democratic issue of our time. The times are too long, we need to resolve issues such as the one concerning the reform of short selling and OTCs.

The second point we are facing is the issue of financial transaction taxation. We need to get to the heart of the matter, and we expect the Polish Presidency to make a concrete contribution in this regard.
More than twenty years have passed since the Schengen agreements were signed.
No one disputes the advantages of free movement, but it must be acknowledged that the current system is no longer suitable for current and future needs.

This is why the Member States and the EU as a whole must work to revise the mechanisms governing Schengen, so that freedom of movement does not come at the expense of our citizens' legitimate need for security.

As far as we know so far, the Commission's guidelines may also be partly acceptable, especially regarding the introduction of a mechanism that allows states to temporarily reintroduce border controls in case of an emergency.
We must see, however, how this will happen and whether the statements will be followed by actions and, above all, concrete results.

Certainly, a general reform of the European border protection system will also be necessary, especially the external borders, where Frontex must become an agency with real intervention and support powers for national authorities as soon as possible.
We must protect our external borders if we want to continue with this Schengen.
It is time for courageous choices in this Europe if one does not want to merely survive.

The crisis has profoundly affected the real lives of European citizens and businesses and risks, if we do not react, irreversibly lowering the social and cultural quality, well-being, and future of young people and Europeans.

Getting out of the crisis means creating remedies for the identified causes, remedies against speculation, which, if necessary, must also have their nails cut, by imposing strict rules on financial markets, remedies that cannot be called into question.

Remedies against recession, remedies against an unbalanced development model that has placed the person a step below profit, remedies against the resurgent nationalism that prevents Europe from making the choices that are its responsibility today.

Above all, it is time to define the tools, the resources, including new ones, to move forward, to ignite the engines of growth, through research, innovation, training, support for productive investments, infrastructure and work, because without work people are without dignity and without rights.
This report, thanks to Pervaiz Bers and colleagues, indicates a possible strategy for a Europe proud and aware of its role.
It is now up to European leaders, if there are any, to take responsibility for implementing it.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, behind the widespread prosperity of our continent there is a hidden Europe, often invisible, which we discuss in terms of numbers, statistics and sociology and not as flesh-and-blood people, often women and children or the elderly, that is, the most vulnerable population.
But Europe will not be credible with its citizens if it does not learn to be consistent, and we here want to be consistent in this Parliament, at this stage of Europe's life.

And so, if we say that we are founding the Union on values, on human rights, I don't believe that we can interrupt or cut so drastically a program for those who don't eat, in other words, for those who don't have the right to food, access to food.

The key points for an unresolved legal issue are the agricultural fund, the social fund, and, if it is to be social, Commissioner, it should not come at the expense of other social programs, but rather be a new, ad hoc fund with appropriate resources.
Let's say we want to ensure food safety for Europeans, but the first right to safety is to have it, the food that is healthy.
So here is our consistency and our commitment.

Let us therefore say that a legal solution is found that provides continuity and that, with the help of non-governmental organizations and volunteer work, guarantees the first fundamental human right: that of civic participation.
Just to support this report and highlight two aspects in particular, one because it fits into the current debate on the report.
review of the common fisheries policy and the fundamental option, which is linked to the regionalization of a policy that has shown all its weaknesses in recent years due to its centralization.
This phase of regionalization finds a particular application in the Black Sea.

I believe that the elements contained in my colleague Iotova's report describe a particular situation, but one that is also repeatable in the rest of Europe. The situation in the Adriatic Sea, in the Mediterranean area, is no different.
In the Tyrrhenian Sea or the Geo Sea, that is, the interactions, especially between European and extra-European fishing, are often very harmful to European markets and European consumers.
The second issue I would like to quickly highlight is the call for a common coastguard.
There is no politics without an exercise of control.

Today, border controls are carried out by disparate forces across Europe, and I believe it is time to consider how one of the first forces, so to speak, of European order, namely the coast guards, could have a common management, greater correlation, and why not, a single European body.
With this hope, I fully support the contents of my colleague Iotova's report.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the disaster that struck the Gulf of Mexico over a year ago prompted the European Commission to reflect on the legislation related to the activity of short-range oil platforms.
The European Parliament, with this report, has also wanted to express its position on the matter, approving a text that requires adequate technical and financial capabilities.
aims to provide high safety standards for industry operators, thereby establishing the European Union's leading role in promoting the safety of offshore activities.
The new measures on the subject requested from the Commission will have to focus on international coordination and a realistic approach that combines all existing excellence.
in the sector at the level of procedures and avoids the creation of new bodies or additional bureaucracy, which would risk moving away from achieving concrete final objectives.

The report, in concrete terms, in addition to greater accountability of operating companies, calls for improved mechanisms for communication and sharing of information and knowledge, and advocates for the strengthening and expansion of the role of the European Maritime Safety Agency's expertise.
It is for all these reasons that I consider the result achieved to be positive, thanks to the negotiation on this text, to which we have expressed our support.
I thank my colleagues Seeber and Schillaciakis, and I also thank Commissioner Heidegger.

I believe that we are here today to discuss and reason in order to truly achieve a strong European climate policy, capable of safeguarding economic development and the well-being of European citizens.
For this reason, Mr. President, international climate policies, as has been mentioned so far, have focused primarily on reducing CO2 emissions.
This proposal highlights that we must also address the fight against other anthropogenic emissions that cause the formation of tropospheric ozone, impacting climate change.

Many things have already been mentioned that I believe it is important to keep in mind. Today, we are able to do this at absolutely reasonable costs, we have the necessary technologies at our disposal, and, although it is debatable, it is primarily CO2 emissions that have an impact.

While it is doubtful that the other greenhouse gases present in the atmosphere are present in much smaller percentages, it is doubtful that their potential is very high and that we will be able to achieve significant results in just a few years or decades.
They are both important.

There are signs, as the Commissioner also pointed out in the United States, I saw a study published in Nature by the scientific agency of the American Department of Commerce, which I believe demonstrates that it is possible.

There are many points of contact with the analysis carried out by our colleagues, and I imagine that these will also be issues that will enable Europe to present itself in Durban with an even stronger, more concrete and important position.

I will conclude by simply recalling, as it has already been mentioned, that in the extraordinarily difficult and delicate moment we are experiencing, we were talking about the homeless just a few minutes ago, there is a sensitivity among European citizens that we must take into account, and therefore, considering that the large

As for sensitivity, obviously that comes first, and regarding jobs, we should also be able to launch a communication campaign that clearly explains to citizens what we concretely want to do in terms of development, their well-being, and job protection.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the single market, free movement and the Lisbon Treaty are all elements that have come into play regardless of a change in our way of legislating, in the European way and in the national way.

If we are to follow up on the commitments that have arisen from these occasions, in particular, we must truly initiate a phase of simplification of the legislative system, a phase of simplification that must produce a different dialogue between Europe and the individual States.

I take this opportunity to suggest a kind of clarity test on our documents when we produce a white paper or a green paper; everything must be more comprehensible, and I would go so far as to say that the real and perhaps strategic proposal for our Europe is to really get started.

The solution to this virtuous phase of initiating registration is to assign a specific mandate to a European Commissioner who will specifically deal with clarifying the legislation and the relationships between the States and Europe itself.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, Mr Council representative and Commissioner, I would like to begin by welcoming, as other colleagues have done, the anti-corruption package that the European Commission approved on 6 June last.
Corruption is a transnational phenomenon and measures on a European scale are needed to combat it.
The vast majority of our European citizens, according to Eurobarometer estimates, believe that Europe must do more.
How can one blame them?

In many member states, there has been a lack of political will to combat corruption, as evidenced by the fact that there are still European countries that have not signed the United Nations Convention against Corruption.

If we consider the devastating impact of corruption on democratic processes, citizens' rights, and trust in the rule of law, it is clear that the national anti-corruption measures adopted by the Member States to date are insufficient to contain an expanding phenomenon.

It is the European Union that must provide a unified and strong response, especially now, in the midst of an unprecedented economic crisis, which is affecting people's lives, the stability of social security and welfare systems, and the ability of institutions to guarantee essential services.
Corruption causes the loss of 120 billion euros every year, equivalent to 1% of the European Union's GDP, and daily deprives the Union and its member states of resources.
they could be used to provide essential services education, childhood, employment, transport, to the detriment of clean resources for supporting people.
We therefore need more courage and more firmness, both by monitoring the implementation of anti-corruption measures and by intensifying and toughening up anti-corruption measures at the Union level.

In particular, we cannot talk about fighting corruption if we are not able to adopt at least minimum standards for defining the crime of corruption, which are not included in the package that has just been passed.
The same applies to the definition of uniform parameters for measuring the extent of the phenomenon in member countries, which is essential for preparing an effective response.
We are in favour, for example, of relaunching the network of EU contact points against corruption, as proposed in the resolution that we will vote on tomorrow.
The crisis is not of yesterday, it has been existing for some years already.
Has the time perhaps come to critically assess the policies followed so far? Has everything always been done well?
We have always carried out appropriate analyses of the situation.
Was the right approach chosen?
The same European Central Bank, which as Minister Rostovsky says saved Europe, has always done well even when, fearing inflation, it raised interest rates?
President Barroso identifies a problem: the speed of the markets and the slowness of politics, but this is not the only problem.

Of course, if one considers that we are still in the implementation phase of July 21, this should at least suggest preparing and organizing the summits and their conclusions better, but politics will always be slower than the markets.
So the point is to look further ahead, shifting the focus to the fight against unemployment and development.

This is the ground that the European Commission must choose today as well, in President Barroso's speech, where there was more concreteness on the deficit and less on the indications of growth and development.

The Commission should go beyond its weakness, say that the priority is fighting unemployment and creating jobs, redistributing wealth and a public investment strategy, while also changing the rules of the new European stability pact.
Mr President, I believe that the challenge for the coming years is to ensure that Europe, as has been said, maintains its position as the leading power.
a world-class tourist destination and at the same time able to enhance its entire territorial heritage in terms of both environmental protection and competitive capacity.

It is a challenging and unpredictable task, not only in light of the opportunities, but also of the aggressiveness of other countries in this sector, from other continents, from China to India, to Brazil.
Now, in this context, as Commissioner Tajani pointed out, it becomes crucial, as also noted in the Commission's opinion that we approved in the Committee on Regional Development.
to put together a strong overall EU strategy on tourism, with an enhancement of the role of the regions and territories.
In this sense, full involvement from the outset is essential, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity of the regions and local authorities.
Furthermore, I believe that the development of integrated tourism networks and projects should be encouraged, starting with the creation of partnerships for the exchange of best practices.
I also think the proposal to identify a European label capable of defining high quality in tourism products is a good one.
Obviously, it will be up to the Commission to better define the priorities, especially from a financial point of view, to ensure that Europe's leadership is maintained in the future.

Madam President, honourable colleagues, the preparation of the common strategic framework for the funding of research and innovation represents one of the greatest opportunities that European development and economy have ahead of them.

It is indeed a matter of acting on the lever that can truly trigger a moment of growth and also of new skilled employment, such as that of researchers and young people who dedicate themselves to the new opportunities of innovation, technology, and related professions.
One observation, in particular, emerges from this work, and one that we must increasingly emphasize in Europe: research and innovation that lead to practical application, that lead to
We need to create new companies that come up with new patents and that are not just pure basic research, pure knowledge, which is important, but not enough to really trigger development.

The second observation is the relationship with local authorities, regions, and territories, which are also an important tool for territorial planning and for bringing together research, universities, centers of excellence, and businesses.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the European schools were created with the aim of ensuring access to education in their mother tongue for the children of officials of the European institutions who are called to work and live abroad in a cultural context different from that of their country of origin.
The first European school was established in Luxembourg back in 1953, on the initiative of a group of officials.
Over the years, considering the positive impact of this form of education, as many as 14 European schools have been established within the various member states.

While recognizing that the system of European schools represents a necessity rather than a luxury, it is evident that more than 50 years after the creation of the first European school, this system may present obsolete aspects and must in some way be adapted and adjusted to new economic and social needs.

I therefore cast my vote in favour of the text by my colleague Mr Cavada, which seeks to increase the involvement of the European Union in supporting and coordinating the actions of the Member States called upon to work towards developing and improving the European schools system.
It is a company that deals with investment, and it is known that investing in education means investing in the future of our young Europeans.

Mr. President, Honorable Colleagues, in recent decades there has been an exponential increase in the number of natural disasters that have caused the death of tens of thousands of people in various parts of the world.
Last year, within the Committee on Development, I followed the work on the report on the European Union's capacity to respond to disasters.
How much more needs to be done to ensure a coordinated European Union response to the increasing number of earthquakes, floods, or tsunamis?
The European Union's response to the Haiti earthquake, for example, clearly demonstrated the complexity of the existing tools and procedures.

Although the Member States and Community institutions acted promptly in terms of sending humanitarian aid, the management of the crisis raised a number of issues in terms of efficiency, coordination and transparency.
That is precisely why I voted in favor of the text by my colleague Elisabetta Gardini, which aspires to greater efficiency in all phases of disaster management, and greater coordination.
among the parties involved and a simplification aimed at avoiding unnecessary overlaps and waste of time that hinder the provision of rapid and effective aid.
Yes, it's just a good initiative, I believe that it will be about building a European policy towards tourism instead.
The European brand is a good idea, but on two issues I want to dwell: there is no sea or coastal tourism without a coastal planning policy.

I believe that the time has come for Europe, precisely to protect this important sector, to produce an initiative in which the concept of the sea and the concept of the coast is not limited to a kind of urban planning that ends at the water's edge and does not involve the sea as a whole.
I believe that an integrated policy is useful in this sense, as well as the need to build everything behind the claims of rural tourism.
an excellent source of income for disadvantaged areas, for areas where there is no longer any work, where it is important instead that depopulation does not continue and there is human settlement.

Well, it's not enough to just make statements there, but we should suggest that Europe and individual states intervene on the fiscal lever. Doing tourism in rural areas might mean paying less tax. Perhaps this is how we really build a real opportunity for the tourist resource and for those who live there.
I would like to express my congratulations on the work carried out by Mr. Fidanza, which logically fits within the framework of actions supporting women.
learned and promoted at the Community level in the field of tourism, after the Lisbon Treaty assigned new powers to the EU in this sector.
I agree and wish to emphasize the statement about the importance of Europe as a unified destination for certified and quality tourism.
The same idea, translated into actions at the level of structures, allocation of resources, funding, coordination of actions between the various levels of government of the countries of the Union.

An approach to be valued and rewarded given the sector in question, with its implications in terms of percentages of GDP produced, employment, and new opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises.
Companies that focus on protecting and enhancing the environment are in a position to develop and thus respond to the main challenges posed by current events.
For all these reasons, I consider this report to be positive, an important signal in the direction of promoting a European policy for tourism.
Mr President, even for recovery, three small considerations: we need more Europe here too.
I believe it is inevitable that on certain issues there is indeed an attitude where not only is more Europe desired, but it is also built.
More Europe means, for example, starting to really think about a common road safety police force, with identical rules in terms of safety protection.
More Europe means having a European training policy, not simply delegating this to individual states, but building, for example, a genuine training policy.
In relation to schools, in relation to young people, and also in relation to the more at-risk categories - a moment ago we mentioned motorcyclists, but we could also talk about truck drivers.
For us, more Europe means having common tools within the machines that improve safety conditions, anti-alcohol tools, and anti-corruption tools.
drowsiness, I believe that they are a targeted strategy to be built with car manufacturers and with European vehicle production.
I believe that if all of this falls within the framework of a common policy, I really think that perhaps conditions will improve.

Mr. President, Honorable Colleagues, this report addresses a topic that is that of global food security. Global means that this topic is not only about world hunger in the poorest countries, but that the issue of food supply concerns all communities, including those in the most developed countries.

Outline some key points, such as the essential coherence between European policies and this goal of global food security, because we are an institution that preaches very well but is often inconsistent in its choices.
I just want to outline, however, three other innovative three-line titles that I believe we should develop more.
Today, the first link in the food supply chain is at risk due to price volatility caused by speculation on food products, which must be curbed if not prevented, including derivatives, etc.
Secondly, the issue of land grabbing, which must be the subject, I believe, of some form of treaty or negotiation, because democracy is at risk, as well as the survival of many peoples.
Third, coherence between supply and energy policies.
We cannot, in order to produce new energy, prevent food from being produced for the peoples of the world.
I voted wholeheartedly in favour of Mrs Zimmer's report, first of all for a matter of safety, because it is an idea that has not been accepted.
It is purely political in nature, because I think it is necessary to bring back to the center of the initiative of the entire European Union this great issue of food security.
It is not just about helping developing countries to address this issue more effectively, but the food crisis, as the demand for food is expected to increase by more than 70% by 2050.

Agricultural products are a major issue that, if not addressed in time and with determination, will become one of the main threats, if not the most important threat, to stability, peace and even democracy, as has been seen.

For this reason, I believe it is essential that the entire European Union, together with its member countries, make every necessary effort, starting with adequate economic investments, as indicated in the report, in this direction, to seriously address this major issue.
Greetings to the Commission, I really must thank all the people who have contributed in recent weeks, in recent months, to the production of this document that we are voting on today in the Chamber.
We worked, I must say very well, and a truly constructive debate developed.
The motion for a resolution that we are voting on today is the result of truly collective work and is the fruit of the contribution of all political forces and of the entire Parliament.

I believe a common and very strong sensitivity has developed regarding this topic, also because we must remember that we live in an era that is truly characterized by an exponential increase in catastrophes.
The numbers, if we look at them in their rawness, are very eloquent: the number of catastrophes in the world has quintupled, if we think about the fact that in 1975
There were 78 catastrophic events recorded, while today we have nearly 400 calamitous events per year.

Mr President, unfortunately, over the past twenty years, the victims of these disasters have been 90 or more, and more than 29 million people have been affected by the disasters, while the economic losses amount to 211 billion euros.
It is evident that we are facing phenomena of such magnitude that require a stronger response, a more effective response, and a truly strong commitment on our part.
We all have the images of the earthquake in Haiti, the flood in Pakistan, and what happened in Japan etched in our minds.
Mr President, Europe itself sees sudden floods, fires and, let us not forget, the ash cloud following the eruption of the Icelandic volcano on its territory every year.
There is no need to go further to assert how important the work being done here in Parliament is, following two principles.
fundamental, which are our guiding stars, the principle of solidarity, which is reinforced by the solidarity clause in the Lisbon Treaty, and the principle of subsidiarity.
we are moving along these lines.

Mr President, the European Union's intervention has always been generous and effective in the past, as I believe is evidenced by the work of our Commissioner Georgieva, but today we need to make a qualitative leap.
A qualitative leap that we are ready to make to move from an ad hoc response to a response instead where the reaction
it can be enhanced by the prior identification of existing resources in the Member States made available to the European Civil Protection Mechanism.
It is also important to emphasize this qualitative leap, from sharing information and responding to emergencies to taking on a planning and monitoring role.
