This is the coordination we hope for, the fundamental role of services such as GMES, and I take this opportunity to also express our concern about what is happening with the budget for these new technologies, which are so crucial.

We have included the importance of communication with citizens, because this is something that the Japanese experience has taught us a great deal about, and it is never enough, it is never sufficient.
And we are waiting for the Commission, to which we ask to present the proposal on civil protection in legislative form as soon as possible.
Oppressed ethnic minorities, Christians forced to live in hiding to practice their faith, priests barbarously murdered while the authorities do nothing - this is today's Turkey.
My party, the Northern League, has always been opposed to Turkey's entry into Europe, because it represents a potential Trojan horse for radical Islamism on our continent.
Today more than ever, we are convinced that the EU must put an end to accession negotiations.
The intolerable threats that Turkey has directed towards Europe must be met with an immediate response.
It is unacceptable for a third country to tell Europe what to do.
Cyprus is a full member of the EU and has the indisputable right to assume the rotating presidency.
Europe must send a clear signal and show itself ready to defend Cyprus by any means in the face of Turkey's political and military arrogance and overbearingness.
Let us immediately halt the accession negotiations and be prepared to suspend trade relations as well.
Mr President, we are experiencing a decisive moment for the future of the euro and, with it, for the entire European project.
To have this awareness would mean to break free from a short-sighted logic that subordinates everything to an ideological desire for budgetary austerity.
We all want the accounts of the various states to be in order, we all want to reduce debt.
However, it is clear that without a smart investment policy capable of revitalizing the economy, there will be no possibility of growth.
The only clear outcome of this approach is that the heaviest costs, as always, will be borne by the weakest citizens.
For this reason, together with the group of socialists and democrats, we voted against this report.
In fact, we continue in only one direction, which is that of austerity without growth, a direction that has so far proved to be wrong.
I greatly appreciate the work that my colleague Ferrera has done with this report.
In fact, out of the package of six legislative proposals dedicated to economic governance, only this one did my group and I vote in favor of.

We did this because, among other things, a clause was included to protect social rights starting from collective bargaining, and there is also a strengthening of the role of Parliament in the adoption of delegated acts.

So, while we cannot change the overall balance of the package of six proposals, this report certainly represents a step forward in achieving, among other things, a surveillance system that takes fundamental rights into account.

And so, in this context, I maintain that a vision, in our view, based solely on a policy of austerity, does not produce positive results; this report certainly constitutes a positive note in contradiction.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, Finland and the Netherlands have taken a stand in the Council for a very simple reason: Bulgaria and Romania are not currently able to guarantee effective border control, and there are three acts of unjust corruption involving the political class and organised crime.
It is not the populist parties and movements who think this way, but Europol, in its 2010 report on organized crime.
There is no populist propaganda, but a serious security problem.

If Bulgaria were to join the Schengen area at this time, police and security agencies predict that the Bulgarian borders, especially the maritime ones, would become an easy target for Turkish and Eastern European crime, and Bulgaria and Romania would become the crossroad for human and drug trafficking.

It is natural that some member states have many reservations about the actual ability of Bulgaria and Romania to ensure effective border controls against organized crime and corruption, and it is therefore absolutely natural that they have opposed their entry into Schengen.
Allowing it now means paving the way for transnational crime and creating a breach in European borders, precisely where there is a very strong migratory pressure from Turkey.
There are many reasons to oppose it, and Europe cannot ignore them.
I would therefore like to know what the Commission and the Council's intentions are regarding this sensitive issue, which in my opinion has so far been dealt with in a
insufficient and without taking into account the dangers that the entry of Bulgaria and Romania would entail, according to the competent bodies in the field of security and international crime.

In my opinion, the Commission and the Council should postpone the entry of these two countries into Schengen and only give the go-ahead when there is reasonable certainty that the entry of Bulgaria and Romania will not have repercussions on the security of European citizens.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the crisis in Europe is entangling the problems of public budgets and private capital with those of the productivity of our businesses in a vicious circle, and the specter of recession is upon us.
If, therefore, the priority of SMEs is crucial, I ask the Commission that it must absolutely, together with Parliament, ensure that the principles, our good principles, are put into practice.
in practice, and that the legislative initiatives of the SBA, the Small Business Act, become concrete practice in the Member States, with a high level of effectiveness and quality.

Imagine, Commissioner, what would happen if all Member States were to bring forward the implementation of the directive against late payments? What a great advantage that would be for SMEs. So SME evidence is important, but we are still at the methodological level.

Of course, it is right to verify whether, when we legislate, we are truly doing so in the interests and to the measure of small and medium-sized enterprises, but we ask that we proceed with great consistency and tenacity, let's say in depth, in creating this framework of opportunities that you have outlined.
We appreciate what the Commission is doing and we are ready with the budget and with the other possibilities we have to support it.
I'll just say a word about credit.
Let's have a clear discussion with the banks, I say to you, Commissioner, because we need to help small and medium-sized enterprises.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, I cast my vote in favour of the text by my colleague, Mrs Wallis.
While not prejudicing the usual avenues of access to justice, I am convinced that an alternative dispute resolution ADR represents a quick and economical alternative to legal disputes.
In addition to being an effective tool for small and medium-sized enterprises, ADR can also have significant development online for the resolution of minor disputes.

Through joint efforts with the Member States, it is therefore necessary to promote the creation of a harmonized legal framework that, by strengthening citizens' confidence in the internal market, can help stimulate the European economy.

The report on the provisions for sectors placed on the market under flexible conditions, to which we cast our favorable vote, was inspired by a measured and realistic approach that resulted in a report

on the one hand, in avoiding the setting of unrealistic and impossible requirements to meet and, on the other hand, in establishing a so-called flexibility regime that is structured in the anticipation of time phases and corresponding quantitative limits of work.

The permitted emissions system provides for the release onto the market of a predetermined annual quota of tractors meeting certain characteristics, thus allowing the adjustment to the set standards to be spread out over time without causing trauma to the production and industrial sectors involved.

Mr. Tartarella, the work carried out has been important and has managed to carefully balance the needs dictated by the major challenges that the European Union is called upon to face at this time, with those of environmental protection and the current context of economic crisis.
Mr. President, Honorable Colleagues, the current global economic crisis, even more severe than the one in 1929, has caused unsustainable imbalances in international economies in recent years.
Trade disparities between countries, financial markets lacking common rules, and instability in banking systems are all potential threats to financial and economic stability.
This resolution, which I support, urgently emphasizes the need for a total reform, new rules, and global economic coordination.

The economy needs a global governance system, open markets, high economic and social standards, more responsible monetary policy, and stricter oversight policies, and international decision-making bodies and economic organizations must be the main actors at the center of this new approach.

Europe, in particular, needs a transparent framework to reduce the instabilities exacerbated by globalization and ensure far-reaching reforms aimed at promoting growth and reducing the debt of individual states.
This is the commitment and resolution that we emphasize to all countries.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, I voted in favour of my colleague Mrs Mattera's report, which analyses the situation of single mothers, who today represent, as has already been mentioned, more than 5% of the population of the European Union.

The European Union therefore has a moral obligation to protect them, and the text approved today supports those policies that can provide concrete help for these women, such as the facilitation for women.
healthcare, flexible work opportunities that allow for a balance between private and professional life, priority access from today to affordable prices and special unemployment benefits.
Only by adopting these measures can we meet the needs of an increasingly significant category in all advanced and industrialized countries.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the budget sets few clear and important objectives within the framework of the EU 2020 strategy, so thanks to the rapporteurs.
It is crucial to focus on investments and not just on prudent budget management.
The alternative would be to passively adhere to the speculative philosophy that characterizes our time.
We can no longer afford to pursue individual interests, but must finally represent a single, cohesive entity ready for confrontation.

I welcome the commitments made on pilot projects and preparatory actions under heading 2, as well as the fact that funding for the integrated maritime policy will not come at the expense of other fisheries initiatives and programmes.

This will allow us to implement new policies for better management of marine resources through extensive research and data exchange on fish stocks, imposing new projects that in the Adriatic area can be used as best practices in other marine areas.

I conclude with a small postscript: in the context of future debates aimed at the ECB, and particularly regarding the fisheries fund, I hope that a greater effort will be made on fisheries control, which is at the heart of the fight against illegal fishing, but also the basis for rebuilding fish stocks.
fish is considered a common good.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the economic, financial and social crisis we are experiencing has clearly highlighted several weaknesses in the European economic and social model.

I believe that one of the most alarming and representative figures of the current situation is the nearly 6 million jobs lost in the last three years, a figure that, if we do not react promptly and effectively, is destined to grow as we move away from this situation.

The text by my colleague Bastos emphasizes that in order to make concrete progress, a better synergy between education, training, and the labor market is necessary, along with policies aimed at ensuring a better match between the demands and supply of this market.
For these reasons, Mr. President, I cast my vote in favor.
I cast my vote in favour of what Mrs Angelilli has presented because it addresses a problem that, as a mother and grandmother, I am deeply concerned about.
Protecting children from sexual exploitation, abuse and the disgusting world of paedophilia means defending our children, our grandchildren, and therefore defending the weakest.
greater prevention, tougher criminal action against those who commit such crimes, and more careful protection of children are the key points of the document voted on today.
Without a doubt, the path is difficult.

I am thinking in particular of the spread of child pornography material via the internet, which can only be combated through close collaboration between Member States, police authorities and providers.

The challenges posed by modernity and the report by our colleague Senata Fidelis, to which we have expressed our vote in favor, require that the citizen be placed in the role of consumer beyond any discussion.

Mr President, families in difficulty in our countries, the elderly, women, young people, the disabled and millions of people and families brought to their knees by the crisis and speculation.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, I cast my vote in favour of the text on the work of the ACP Joint Parliamentary Assembly, which, thanks to the quality of the work carried out, has established itself as a key player in cooperation between the North and South of the world.

I myself, as a member of that assembly, participated in the meetings held in Brussels and the work sessions that took place in Tenerife in April 2010 and in Kinshasa, Congo, in December of the same year.

It was precisely thanks to these visits that I was able to witness firsthand, as I had already done in Angola in 2009, the sad conditions in which certain peoples live on a daily basis, and at the same time assess the efforts made by the ACP to improve things.

In conclusion, I feel it is important to emphasize, especially in a particular historical political moment, particularly for the countries of North Africa and the Middle East, how the role played by the ACP has been significant.

It is crucial, especially in the context of overseeing negotiations for economic partnership agreements, to promote transparency in these processes and the development of disadvantaged local communities.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, I personally find the establishment of a European heritage label interesting.

The defining element of the European label is not the beauty of a site, but the symbolic value that it has represented or represents for the integration of European citizens on the path towards improved inter-point dialogue.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, we are all aware of the important role played by the International Criminal Court, which is responsible for prosecuting those who commit war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide.
Unfortunately, in recent times, the Court has increasingly been the target of unjust political attacks.
His arrest warrants have often been ignored, and for this reason the current budget is not proportionate to the efforts and commitment made.

I therefore cast my vote in favour of the text approved today because it is the task of the European Union to undertake all political, diplomatic and logistical actions to support the Court and guarantee its independence and proper and effective functioning.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the phosphates in household washing machine detergents end up in the water systems in European rivers, streams and lakes.

Phosphorus causes an acceleration in the reproduction of various life forms, as a result, algae and other rapidly developing plant species proliferate excessively when there is an increase in the presence of phosphorus in an aquatic environment.
This excessive growth of algae deprives other living organisms of oxygen, can also produce toxins that destroy fish and plant species, thus reducing the quality of the water itself.

I therefore cast my vote in favour of the text voted on today, because in order to purify Europe's water resources, it is desirable to reduce the amount of phosphorus that flows into the waters of our continent.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the text presented by my colleague Mr Lisek analyses the possible measures to be implemented to reduce defence costs at a time when the financial crisis is having a heavy impact on the Community budget.
The main proposals concern better coordination of defense system planning, pooling and sharing of defense capabilities, and support for research and technological development.
I therefore agree with the rapporteur's view that the economic and financial crisis that has hit us could be an opportunity for integration of the
European Union defense policies, providing the impetus to develop and finally implement those ambitious reforms that have been stalled for years.
For these reasons, I cast my vote in favor.
Mr President, a review of the European Neighbourhood Policy has become necessary following the Arab Spring and the events that have ensued.

It is evident that, at the present state of affairs, relations with the countries in question must be more focused on cooperation, in order to ensure the priority of democracy and security on both sides of the Mediterranean.

In this regard, I believe that intercultural and interreligious dialogue is essential to strengthen mutual respect and tolerance with partner countries in the neighborhood, while at the same time promoting the fight against terrorism and extremism.
For these reasons, Mr President, I naturally voted in favour.
Mr. President, yesterday in Florence an extremely serious event occurred that evokes horror and dismay. A man of great value, a man of great value, a man of great value.
A 50-year-old armed man opened fire in two markets in the city of Florence on five citizens of Senegalese origin, two of whom died and three are now hospitalized in serious condition.
The murderer then committed suicide.
It is a racist far-right extremist, a former Xenonist, who wanted to kill people he did not know, guilty only of having black skin.
Florence is my city and, before being elected to the European Parliament, I was mayor of Florence for ten years.
Florence is a civil and democratic city, awarded a gold medal for its resistance to Nazifascism.

Yet it was precisely in Florence that this abominable racist crime took place, demonstrating that Nazi-fascist madness can manifest itself anywhere and one must never think that it has been definitively eradicated.
Mr President, I ask you to express the European Parliament's condolences and to reaffirm its commitment against all forms of racism and for the respect and rights of every human being.

in developed countries or in countries not affected by conflict, with aid obviously also hindered by the unstable security situation.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, Europe is sinking, the stock markets are collapsing, the centralist Europe of the financial lobbies is falling apart, but the Danish Presidency is opening its six-month term by promising total loyalty to the Commission's plans for creating a super economic government for the continent.

Instead of focusing on the measures to be implemented to save the destinies of 500 million citizens, the Danish government promises to act as a loyal rogue guard of the Euro technocracy in the Council.
Other passages then do not find me in agreement at all.
First of all, I do not see how the acceleration of the EU enlargement process towards the Balkan countries can be proposed as a priority today.

Mr President, Honourable Bizzotto, I do not deny that we need to protect the rights of homosexuals, what I deny is that there are no homosexual families in Italy.

Homosexuals will never exist, simply because the family that needs to be protected, the one that the European Parliament should also protect, is the traditional family, the one formed by a woman, a man, and their children.
That all seems to me to be quite elementary.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, first of all, I too would like to join in the warm greetings for our colleague Mr Lechner, and also in the appreciation of his work, which has proceeded with competence, tenacity and determination.

by working to meet the interests of citizens in their daily lives and especially of these millions and millions who, living on the borders of different states, ask us to be

The solutions that have been proposed are intelligent and innovative, for example, those who must make a will have been given the option to choose between their habitual residence or their state of origin.
This makes a decision more elastic, given that there are such profound, truly very profound, differences between one state and another, which could constantly complicate the issue of succession.
However, we have also been given certainty of law, because once the legal domicile or habitual residence or country of origin has been chosen, it cannot be changed.

This results in a limitation of the judges' discretion and also a limitation of the conflicts that can arise, and therefore a more peaceful way of proceeding in this field, and therefore there is more freedom and more certainty.

And then there is the certificate of succession, here we believe that certificates are of little importance, this creates the conditions for the heir to have a more flexible and certain position in the face of all the possible difficulties that may arise for him.
This is a fact that positively characterizes this law.

And then it's true, this law is not perfect, there are problems concerning the executor of the will, less so, the practicality of direct inheritance and so on, but I don't just want to say a word of a political nature.
We hope that the Council will approve this text, we hope that it will become a regulation, but we must not put a tombstone on this text, because we cannot even get along with the European Union.
England is in a different situation with Great Britain, because Europe cannot do without Great Britain and therefore we should proceed to overcome these difficulties later.
Thank you, sir.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the European Union has produced an enormous amount of laws, rules to build European law and has created the European area, called the Stockholm plan.
There is a discrepancy between this corpus, this legislative monument, and the use that citizens make of it, which is numerically and percentage-wise very low.
On the other hand, national judges, the national lawyers of individual states, have grown up within the law of their own country and have a predominant education in this field.
This is the point, while we think that the true European judge is the national judge who changes his mindset and imbues himself with knowledge of European law.

For this reason, before discussing training, we must talk about extensive communication to citizens and legal professionals, so that they become the bearers of this great innovation and increase the willingness to use the benefits of this right.
But above all, it is a grassroots movement that must be created in in-service training; you cannot lecture like to schoolchildren when training adult and highly professional judges.

One must stimulate curiosity in handling one's own cases, in connecting with other colleagues, and in finding solutions, since today common law and civil law converge, they are no longer as distant as they once were within the legal culture.

This is the real point in our proposals and I am pleased that the European Commission has been convinced of these aspects. In our view, we are calling for a change of direction, with more legal studies than judicial training.
There is a very interesting example in Holland called Eurinfra, which is a network of officials in each court who disseminate this knowledge and encourage magistrates to do the same.
Here is the essence of our project, and we hope it will receive full support from the Commission.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, I would like to begin by expressing my sincere appreciation for the work done by my colleague Mr Giegold on this own-initiative report, and I would also like to remind you that he and others share an active presence in the Social Economy Intergroup in this Parliament.

My political group, as you know, believes that the social model is one of the founding characteristics of the European integration project, therefore not just one of many policies, but a policy that defines our project itself.

And these days, with attacks also linked to necessity, cuts in public spending, etc., we still defend this conviction, this priority. We know that it can be an updated, modified social model, but we also believe that it must be maintained, defended, and reaffirmed precisely as a priority.

So I believe that, in this same vision, we must also value economic entities that engage in business, that produce goods and services, such as cooperatives, and that play a very particular role in the so-called European social economy.

they reiterate that production can be achieved, good things can be done, efficiency can be attained, even if profit is not the goal, but rather, for example, employment, welfare, enhancement of work, and contribution to the life of the local community.

That is why I conclude, Mr President, that it is important for Europe to provide the necessary tools for an active policy, and that a good statute for cooperatives - not the current unusable one - can be a way to help this very important sector.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the role of the cooperative movement has always been important in building a more balanced and fairer economic dimension.

It is a time of great change and, at this moment when we are going through one of the most serious economic and social crises since the post-war period, the role of cooperative societies becomes crucial.

there has been a robust development of the cooperative dimension in the economy, this has led to an increase in employment, more skilled work, and a more balanced redistribution of the wealth produced.
It is therefore positive that the European Union has adopted a statute for cooperative societies, but now more than ever it is necessary for there to be a real simplification of the rules.
We need to give new impetus to the creation of a common European framework in the field of cooperation, and this must be done by helping and not by creating bureaucratic obstacles.
That is why I voted in favour of this resolution and I hope that the Commission and the Council will actively work to resolve the problems mentioned.

The salvation of millions of unemployed Europeans does not depend on the limping assistance offered by the European Agglomeration Fund. The collected data reveal that most of the fund's beneficiaries are unable to find new employment, while the luckier ones are reintegrated into the labor market with fixed-term contracts, some of only six months.
In many cases, the unemployed give up on this fund because they doubt its usefulness.
The EGF is not a solution or a plug for the disastrous consequences of a European trade policy that has been managed dangerously and too lightly by the Commission.

To combat the scourge of structural unemployment, Europe must curb its excessive openness to the markets of developing countries, whose real competition is the primary cause of the failures of our companies.
Until Europe stops promoting economic self-harm by defending a short-sighted position towards global trade flows, our companies will continue to fail.
The fund can only provide temporary support, but it is not through training courses that our unemployed will find peace and security.
I believe that today is a great achievement for the European Parliament, because what Attila, the President of the Commission, wrote on July 15 was a great achievement.
President Buzek said we must set up an anti-mafia commission, and I remember that many colleagues from different countries said, "But the mafia is a problem of Sicily and Italy."

Today, having been recognized by colleagues from all over Northern Europe that there is a problem of organized crime in Europe and having the will to fight together, I believe that this is a great and important achievement, and I want to say thank you, Mr. President, thank you to the entire Parliament.
Mr. President, thank you to Mr. Sondahl for such a comprehensive presentation, which has led to a wide-ranging discussion.

I would also like, first of all, to reiterate our solidarity with the families of the victims of the serious clashes that took place on December 16 in Zanzibar, as well as our concern for the subsequent development of events.

What was originally essentially a union warning degenerated into the very serious accidents in which 17 people lost their lives, and in the days following the accidents into the arrests of journalists and opposition representatives.

It is in everyone's interest, and as demonstrated by Kazakhstan itself, to shed full light on the events, and I hope that today will be remembered solely as a positive occasion for our Parliament to delve into what has happened so far.

and reiterate our call for an investigation that will reassure the international community that responsibility for the events in San Jos will be clarified and those responsible will be prosecuted with the utmost respect for the principles of legality and the protection of human rights.

The delegation, which had the honour of chairing the meetings, had the opportunity to listen to the explanations provided by the Kazakh authorities and also by some NGOs that are very active in monitoring events in this country.

The willingness of the Kazakhstani authorities to provide explanations, as well as the promises of further clarification, are certainly positive elements that should obviously be appreciated by all of us.

This is also why I would like to stress the need to maintain a certain balance, a balance that I would have liked to see highlighted in the text of the resolution that we will be voting on tomorrow and which I believe is very important.

In my opinion, it might have been appropriate to postpone the decision pending the conclusion of the official investigations, to which it would have been useful to add an official mission by international bodies.

The undeniable need to clarify what happened and the need to appeal for increased efforts by Kazakhstan to improve progress on the path to democracy must also be constantly accompanied by a renewed commitment and open, constructive dialogue with this country.

Mr President, I voted in favour of this proposal, as it aims to update the 2004 regulations in order to adapt to changes in the national legislation of the Member States in the field of social security and to keep pace with changes in social reality that affect the coordination of the security systems themselves.

The present proposal also incorporates proposals from the Administrative Commission for the Coordination of Social Security Systems, which aim to improve, modernize, and acquire in accordance with Article 72(f) of the previous regulation.

The amendments contained in this proposal are intended to guarantee legal certainty for the parties concerned and also aim to ensure appropriate coordination at the level of the European Union of national social security systems.

it also reflects the regulatory changes that have taken place at national level and it was necessary to approve it because it takes into account the recent developments in the field of cross-border mobility that affect the coordination of social security systems.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the credibility of the European Union at international level and the effectiveness of its human rights policies certainly pass through the condemnation of violations, abuses and human rights violations.

But it is also of absolute importance to avoid gender disparity between citizens and communities, discrimination, crimes committed outside the framework of armed conflicts, the lack of respect for women, minors, and the vulnerable in general, and persecutions based on religion or belief.

The European Union's human rights policy and other external policies should be aligned, thereby promoting democratization and supporting the fight against social inequalities, especially in times of economic crisis like the present.
Mr President, I would like to thank my colleagues Mr Arsenis, Mr Patrao Neves, Mr Romeva and their assistants for their substantial contribution to the success of this initiative.
Fish is a common good, as it provides 15% of the protein for over 3 billion people, and the livelihoods of over 500 million people depend on fishing and aquaculture.
This makes it a true global public good.
The approval of this statement indicates to the Commission a precise path on the need to disseminate responsible conduct both among fishing communities and in consumer behavior.

The debate on the reform of the common fisheries policy now has an additional reason to support actions that move European policy away from the narrow focus on methods of resource extraction and towards a policy of rules that are directed inward.

On the contrary, a strategy is suggested that focuses on the sea as a privileged location to increase its reproductive capacity, both in inland waters and through innovative methods of fishing agreements with third countries.

Moreover, all of this is not only about protecting the environment and maintaining biodiversity, but also about responsible fishing, economic and social sustainability, and the specific interests of fishermen and our economies.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the third amendment to the rules,
1083 submitted by the European Commission in a short time contains provisions aimed at creating a European risk-sharing instrument.

The objective is indeed to address the difficulties encountered by some Member States in raising the necessary private funding for the implementation of investment projects that can only be partially financed using public funds.

Although the path to overcoming the economic crisis is still long, I consider the work done to reach a compromise text that has set a maximum for the funds allocated to the financial instrument and better defined the risk-sharing tools to be fruitful.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the economic crisis, technological development and demographic changes have transformed society and the labour market in Europe in recent years.

For this reason, I express my vote in favor of the text by my colleague Toques, which aims to modernize higher education systems in order to achieve the objectives set by the Europe 2020 strategy and promote social, cultural, and economic development within the Union.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, I will not dwell on this for long because in the short time available I would just like to touch on a few things.

I believe that this seventh environmental action programme can certainly prove to be a useful tool, but only if it is based on a vision of the future that takes into account the need to maintain a solid European industrial base, which is essential for maintaining a decent and acceptable level of employment.

I believe that an absolute priority is for this program to ensure the most effective implementation of existing regulations before setting new ones.

I am deeply convinced that, in order to address today's environmental challenges, we must rely on future environmental policies that are based on solid evidence, the most up-to-date scientific knowledge, and the most advanced scientific understanding.

I am concerned about Article 24, which refers to the ecological footprint as an absolute indicator. It represents an indicator and an empirical model of reality, not reality itself. We must keep this in mind.

This has many limitations; it tells us how much we affect the environment, but it does not estimate, for example, the quality of the environment, so my concerns remain and I urge everyone to take this into account.
