So I think it is certainly a positive example, a good example, because it is a sector that is of fundamental importance to the economy, which is a sector that is of fundamental importance to the economy.

But you will have understood, Commissioner, that there is a widespread desire in this Parliament, particularly in the speeches of two of my colleagues, Mardurel Goebbels and my group, but also many others.
There are others who would like this good example to become excellent and for us to move towards, and this measure partly provides for, a result of zero roaming, because it is possible.
We are utopians.

No, because a European internal market requires that tariffs be similar between domestic and non-domestic, there is no longer any difference when we talk about a single market, and above all because there is no technical justification for the increase in costs.
I remember when, in 2007, we started talking about voice roaming, the first third roaming we've ever had.
There was a certain disbelief and also a certain difficulty, not on the part of the Commission, I must give credit to her predecessor, Commissioner Reding.

The difficulties were widespread, coming from those who said that the position of a true market does not involve regulation of tariffs, that prices are political, that it belongs to an old conception of the left, and so on. There were also those who said that it does not work and that it thus hinders the market, but in the end we did it.
The realization that there were no technical justifications for the increase in costs led to a breakthrough.
So the world is moving, things are becoming more and more, let's say, possible, which is why I think an even more daring outcome is possible.
One last point, as I cannot make any more observations today, we had a delegation of Tunisian citizens here, I do not know if they are still present.
Here perhaps, among its many benefits, this enlargement outside the EU makes us understand that the possibility of use, without the real fear of costs, also helps democracy.
In Europe, there are more than 120 million broadband users, with at least 70 million citizens using their mobile devices to connect to the internet, work, study, or simply stay informed.
Thanks to this regulation, the European Union has finally decided to intervene in favor of all these consumers, reducing the cost of international telephone traffic, voice, data, and SMS.
This is a positive decision because the price reduction program will lead to an average decrease in rates of 35% over the next three years.

However, this is not enough in a difficult time like the present one, both from an economic and employment perspective. Communication, new technologies, and innovation are primary assets that Europe must defend with more courage.
Every European citizen must be able to move freely between member states, using the telephone rate set by their national operator.

No more fraud and exorbitant bills for those traveling within the EU. If we really want to give a concrete response to citizens, let's create a kind of telecommunications Schengen, which no longer imposes different tariffs on citizens depending on the countries in which they operate.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, I was part of that delegation from the European Parliament that went to Sicily in November last year.
Our head of delegation, Cecilia Wistrom, wrote a letter to the Italian minister, the minister of the interior chancellor, and received a response that gave us fairly clear answers.

I would like to point out, above all, that after that visit to Italy, the government changed, and the approach to the situation also changed, but the situation itself in the countries from which the migratory flow predominantly originated also changed.
However, this should not distract us from the need for a careful analysis of what happened and also of the current situation.
The most relevant fact that is still relevant today is Lampedusa's status as an unsafe port, the closure of the first aid and reception center in Contrada Imbriagola following the fire of the

The first was the 2011 disaster that damaged it but only partially, that is, one dormitory was destroyed, one out of seven buildings in the structure was damaged, and then the project was effectively cancelled.

Now, the consideration is that in the Mediterranean, the only unsafe port was that of Tripoli during Gaddafi's time, and I do not find this analogy flattering, given that migratory flows, even if significantly reduced in number, also for seasonal reasons, are becoming increasingly numerous.

They have certainly not stopped, and it is important that a first aid and reception service operates in Lampedusa, which is the first port of call for those arriving from the other side after journeys that are certainly not easy or risk-free, as the Somali shipwrecked who arrived in Lampedusa know all too well.

In April of this year, after seeing 10 people die on the boat they were traveling on, or the 20 who were transferred from Linosa because there was no room in other reception centers, or the 18 who are still living in the stadium's locker rooms on Linosa.

The tourist residence in Cala Creta, where they are currently housed, is certainly not a CIE or a Cara, and in the meantime, both the healthcare system and the possibility of requesting asylum have been dismantled in Lampedusa.
Everything is entrusted to the goodwill and kind hearts of the carabineri on duty or the citizens and volunteers of Lampedusa.
Another consideration to be made is the function that the center itself had assumed in the recent past.
Allowing thousands and thousands of people to gather in a place that, due to its capacity and intended function, could only accommodate a few hundred, against all legal and ethical norms.

The fact that a territory of just a few square kilometers, already difficult due to its location and logistical challenges, was forced to accommodate a number of people greater than its own population should have been enough to drive the point home.
We must reflect on the responsibilities for a situation of extreme tension.
It is not possible to be trapped in the fire itself.
I believe that my colleague Rinaldi's excellent report was successful in the Chamber.
I absolutely share the flattering opinion on the report.

Nevertheless, I would like to raise a small issue: our Europe, in relation to this new world that is seeking to find democracy and different economic conditions, is a Europe divided by the Mediterranean.

It is precisely the Mediterranean that I would like the Commission to pay particular attention to, both in terms of environmental aspects and economic transactions that take place in the Mediterranean.
Nedran is a fishing place.
We are building a new fisheries policy in Europe, which will set very strict rules on the part of Europe.
On the other hand, there are no rules.
So why not use forms of fisheries agreements, support for these countries so that those countries apply the same rules that apply in Europe?

This would be beneficial for European fisheries, it would be beneficial for the sea, for environmental conservation, to ensure that this divide becomes less and less of a divide, and more and more a homogeneous place upon which to build the future of Europe and of this new world.

With the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, the European Parliament has become a fully-fledged institutional subject in the field of security policies and therefore has the right to actively and decisively participate in the priorities of the internal security strategy and the security model of the Union.

The report by my colleague Borsellino identifies the five key areas for which concrete actions have been proposed and calls for greater judicial and police cooperation between Member States to combat organized crime and terrorism.
I believe it is of particular importance to strongly consider the development of prevention policies, which are fundamental tools for ensuring a European area of freedom, security and justice.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, with the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, the foundations have been laid for the development of integrated criminal law within Community law.

By affirming the importance of mutual recognition, the harmonization of protection standards, and the principle of the presumption of innocence, it is important to emphasize that the law must be extremely clear and easily understandable, so that everyone can clearly understand which actions constitute a crime and which do not.
This is particularly true for directives that must be reciprocal to national law.
Any lack of charity could give rise, in part, to divergent interpretations of the law.

I therefore believe that only close collaboration between European institutions on the principles and methods to be followed can guarantee a coherent and high-quality European strategy in the field of criminal law.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the European Union guarantees the general interests of consumers against unfair business practices, misleading advertising and abusive contractual clauses, but there is no solution.
It is questionable whether those consumers who are more vulnerable due to age, physical or mental health problems, or simply due to a lack of proper information, should be protected more carefully.
I therefore cast my vote in favour of the text by my colleague Mrs Perez, because I agree that the creation of a strategy for consumer rights
of the so-called most vulnerable contribute not only to their social inclusion, but also to ensuring a safer, fairer and more competitive single market.
The report by our colleague Perez, to which we have given our vote of approval, deals with the need to consider the development of a report for the future.

One strategy is aimed at protecting the rights of the most vulnerable consumers, in view of the strategy that the European Commission and the Member States will be called upon to develop in this regard.
Consumer vulnerability conditions arise from various causes and can potentially affect everyone.

For this reason, it is necessary to provide protection for this category alongside the general protection of consumers, and to develop a targeted strategy in this regard that, while taking into account the complex nature of the problem, avoids

On the one hand, the formulation of static and rigid definitions that are unable to consider all the facets of the issue and the different possible forms of vulnerability, and on the other hand, it prevents the creation of new types of discrimination.
It is therefore necessary to arrive at the definition of specific and targeted protective measures.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the management of bluefin tuna fishing has a long, rather complex history, dating back to the 1990s, and is currently probably the most strictly regulated by the European Union.
Despite substantial investments in monitoring having led to greater compliance with regulations, there are still concerns about the problem of overfishing.
I therefore expressed my support for the Romeva i Rueda report, which proposes a reduction in the allowable catch rate, greater control, and the strengthening of measures to reduce capacity.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the relations between the European Union and China clearly show situations of imbalance at a commercial level.
It is therefore incumbent upon European institutions to strive to help European businesses emerge from the crisis and succeed in making access to international markets more equitable.
I therefore expressed my support for this report, particularly sharing the rapporteur's concerns about the application of the principle of reciprocity to relations.
relations between the European Union and China to allow fair competition in international markets and the demand for greater protection of intellectual property rights.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, there is still a long way to go, but today's can be an important step towards finally introducing and implementing a financial transaction tax.
I understand the prudence, caution, and need for gradualism expressed by Commissioner Schmetta, as well as the technical problems rightly discussed by Minister Vestager.

But precisely for this reason, I hope that Parliament will express a clear political will, with a large majority, to provide impetus and drive to the necessary initiatives to address the problems that still remain unresolved, especially at the Council level.
We all want to carefully assess the impact of this tax, but it is not right to stir up unfounded fears, which can also lead to contradictory and counterproductive choices.
I am referring, for example, to the logic behind the proposal for exemptions.
If you are concerned about reducing the impact of the tax, then it is important to have a tax base as broad as possible, with a low rate, and not to try to extend exemptions indefinitely.

For those concerned about the impact on small investors, it is worth noting that the tax is progressive, meaning that those who carry out more transactions and make more investments are taxed more heavily.
of transactions and it is clear that the competent authorities must in any case ensure that attempts are not made to pass on any costs to customers and end users.
I therefore hope that Parliament will vote in favour of this tax by a large majority.

Mr President, honourable Members, since 1990, the European Union has been providing economic aid in the form of grants, loans or a combination of both to countries experiencing short-term balance of payments difficulties through the instrument of macro-financial assistance.
The rather long timeframes, added to the difficulties revealed by the decision-making criteria used so far, have made it necessary to formulate some changes to the regulations.

I therefore welcome the proposal introduced in the new regulation, which aims to make the assessment criteria faster and more effective, and to agree on clearer rules and conditions for the provision of macro-financial assistance.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, there are approximately 100 million European citizens involved in various forms of voluntary work.

From major sporting events to cultural events, the role played by volunteers is crucial, and we must not overlook the work of those people who rush to provide help and solidarity in the event of serious natural or environmental disasters.
Volunteering constitutes one of the broadest expressions of active citizenship and a crucial activity for the development of democratic values and equality within the European Union.
For this reason, I hope for the development of high-quality volunteering, both national and cross-border, and the removal of the existing obstacles.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, from the communications sector to finance, transport, energy, culture and health, the role played by technology is becoming increasingly relevant.
The increasing use of the Internet and digital media makes the problem of cybersecurity one of the priorities on the European agenda.

Information and communication technologies can indeed promote economic and social development only if the existing regulations guarantee user security with regard to data privacy and intellectual property rights.
For this reason, only full international cooperation involving member states, institutions, and industry can create a robust system capable of introducing effective measures to ensure cybersecurity.
Madam President, thanks to the Commissioner, important and shareable things have been said, which are very important.
I find it truly, as he said, shocking that we have each lived in our own country with the numbers and figures that we heard earlier from our colleague Oconio.
2020. But it is equally evident that this scandal has really highlighted the need for a careful evaluation of the European legislation currently in force on medical devices.

Unfortunately, this fraud has highlighted the shortcomings we have discussed in this Chamber, which the Commissioner has so well represented, so I would not like to dwell on this aspect in the short time available to me.
I believe it is important to put everything in place so that we can offer the best to our citizens.
But I believe that this scandal, which has taught us so much, could also be an opportunity to take a further step forward, and I agree with what the colleague said earlier.

The communication made to patients is really poor, it always only emphasizes the positive aspect, it says that there is a kind of eternal youth, of promised beauty, there are no prostheses that are absolutely free of risks.

I believe that this awareness, especially when it comes to pure cosmetic surgery, must be truly communicated to people, to girls, because we know that there are very young girls who are approaching this type of procedure.
So I see that you are absent with conviction and therefore I recommend that we really get to work, time is short, we should have already done it yesterday.
Mr President, honourable Members, the Council regulation on the multiannual plan for the hake stock was adopted before the Treaty came into force, and therefore alignment was necessary.

This regulation, the first in the fisheries sector to be aligned with the treaty, is therefore of considerable importance, as the solution adopted in this case could influence the decision-making procedure applicable to other multiannual plans.
This is why I am casting my vote in favor.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, from Seveso to Bhopal to Toulouse, there have been numerous environmental disasters in Europe in recent years that have put the health of European citizens at risk.

The text by my colleague Ader concerns the revision of the SES II directive, which aims to mitigate the effects of accidents involving significant quantities of dangerous and highly polluting substances released into the environment.

The revised regulations, which will come into effect from June 2015, are aimed at protecting the environment and, above all, at limiting tragic consequences for citizens' health, and therefore I cast my vote in favor.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, I too would like to thank Mr Stevenson for the excellent work and approach he has given to this report, which essentially addresses the two main issues.

This is not just about a simple herring management plan, it is essentially about ensuring a future for fishermen in some respects and planning at sea to ensure that this, over several years, has its protections.
But the key point of this report is and remains the issue of delegated acts.

I believe that the Council must accept the approach given by the Lisbon Treaty and I also think that the time has come for Parliament, in some way, with a perhaps more authoritative voice than that of the European Parliament.
whether it is a debate within the fisheries committee or a debate on a report concerning hake, have the courage to take a very clear and strong position on the issue of delegated acts.
We demand the right for these matters to be handled through the ordinary procedure.

So perfectly that the issue also involves, in addition to many other sectors of fishing, which will incidentally worsen with respect to the ongoing reform, but it concerns issues related to agriculture and other topics.
The essential point is to respect the will of Parliament.
In drafting this report, no account was taken of the parties directly concerned, the road haulage companies.
In Italy, 91% of freight transport is carried out by road.
Their rights will be ignored if this report is approved in its current form.
In many committees of this Parliament, we work daily to reduce the financial and administrative burden on our businesses, but reports like these undermine our efforts.
We must make every effort, because they will suffocate companies with new bureaucratic burdens, ruinous economic losses, and new forms of unfair competition.

It would have taken very little to achieve a balanced agreement that did not forget the right to survival of our companies in a very difficult economic period, but a dialogue of this kind was not possible.

On the contrary, the report deliberately ignored even previous legislative acts of the European Union, such as the 2002 Working Time Directive, and even ignored European Commission documents that recognized the dangers of practices like retrofitting, which is instead being proposed again in this report.
The document we will vote on tomorrow, colleagues, will ask you to forget the positive achievements made in recent years, and once again it will be European companies that will foot the bill.

Just to say, Mr. President, that ACTA was a very serious political mistake, let's leave aside the legal one, it has determined a reaction in the world of immense proportions and this is enough to say that it is a political mistake.
But why the Benses?
Why did it create the suspicion that access to the web, which is a great modern revolution, would really be closed off?
And why is that?
Because he made the mistake of conflating counterfeiting and piracy, which are two distinctly different phenomena.
The way to combat counterfeiting has nothing to do with copyright.
And then there is another mistake, which has cut off Parliament in an important activity that it has been carrying out for some time, which is to create a new copyright.

The old copyright that existed before the web. So the point is that we need to work on copyright and put ACTA aside, which is an obstacle, and reject it and exclude it, because it is an obstacle to our work.

Fortunately, after months and years of hesitation, the Commission has brought two important measures - orphan works and the upcoming one on copyright management companies - to the attention of Parliament.
So, let's work on this by reflecting with our brains and not just our emotions, but without having any cards up our sleeves.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, I simply wish to add my voice to the praise that this report has received in this House regarding the need to strengthen the European Union's capacity to meet the challenges of the future.
to be a place where it is possible to invest, produce and manufacture in line with our vision of an inclusive, socially and environmentally sustainable economy.

So I believe that some of the guidelines here are very useful in this measure, others can be added, and I think it's important to gather this information, to work increasingly towards making attractiveness the main priority.
the result of territorial policies, territorial marketing and openness, which involve the territory proposing a productive and industrial vocation.

that originates from the territory and respects all environmental and European political compatibilities that go in this direction, from the territory and from Europe a voice that is attractive for investments and growth.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, when we talk about sensitive issues such as the authorisation of products and substances for use in organic production, we are talking about the protection of the health of European citizens.

It is important to meet consumer expectations regarding the quality of organic products circulating in European markets, and it is equally important to ensure the proper application of Community legislation by the authorities, bodies, and operators concerned.
For this reason, I express my vote in favor of my colleague's text.
Pia's initial comments on the Council, now the phase of reductive reading has begun and this is wrong, because important steps forward have been made.
Consider, for example, the breaking of destructive ties between banks and public debt, and the weak plan for employment and work.

The spirit of revival and a renewed path of political unity seems to be dawning once again in the European institutions, after so much sluggishness and torpor, and a desire for real progress towards greater integration.
We have seen strong unity between Parliament and the Commission on this.

I am not talking about winners and losers, but it is undeniable that there has been a new institutional and political vitality compared to the past diarchy, which was the negation, the very antithesis of the community spirit.
There has been an initiative and activism from multiple countries, not to create new exclusive axes, but to build a common consensus that respects all member states.
This is the path of the political goal of unity, without which any banking, fiscal, and monetary union will be completely insufficient.
On June 6, with the Council's decision to give member states the option to reintroduce border controls, a new Europe was born, a Europe that had the courage to fulfill everyone's desire.
and greater security for its citizens, is finally inspired by a more mature interpretation of the concept of solidarity, which is reduced to the defense of the rights of its peoples above all else.

To President Schulz, even though he is not present, I say that this historic decision does not represent an interinstitutional incident, but rather respect for the will of the citizens and not that of the Euro-bureaucracy that for years has pretended not to understand what is really happening outside the glass palace.
No imaginary influx of illegal immigrants, Mr. President Schulz, but a 35% increase in illegal immigrants, as measured by Frontex, in 2011.

My only regret is that the scenes of political deadlock that have taken place in this Chamber and at the last plenary session have taken time away from a more useful and constructive activity: questioning ourselves as to why it was not we who defended the interests of our citizens, but the Member States.

If Parliament does not find its soul and the courage to go against the populist approach, the sterile platitudes that it has been muddling through with for too long, it will continue to be a follower rather than a leader in the construction of the European project.
I wish to draw the attention of this House to the fact that yesterday was a
We have officially announced that the Higgs boson has been measured and concretely identified.
the particle that gives mass to all the others and their existence, and this happened on European soil.
Science gives life to our land, civilization, and well-being, and for a moment we can aspire to return to being a world science capital.
Utopia is the characteristic of man who invents a utopia and wants to realize it, and it is for science and for this wonderful ambition of man that today a person

A blind person who cannot see with their eyes can see with their hands or read a book with their ears, and a young South African boy who cannot use his legs can run in the Olympics in a speed competition.
Well, Europe must be the home of science; this great event that will open up new frontiers of knowledge must be fully supported by Europe.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, all too often within the European Union, victims of crime do not report incidents due to fear or lack of trust in the institutions.
The text voted on today aims to strengthen the rights of crime victims and ensure they receive the same level of protection, assistance, and access to justice in safe conditions.
all EU countries, paying particular attention to those victims who are at a high risk of suffering further prejudice or intimidation during the criminal proceedings.

Of particular importance is therefore the recognition of victim status not only for those who have suffered prejudice as a result of a crime, but also for family members and the deceased as a result of the crime.
On September 11, the Catalan people demonstrated peacefully in Barcelona.
One million people have called for Catalonia's independence from Spain.
On October 15, British Prime Minister Cameron signed the agreement to allow the referendum for Scotland's independence from London.
In Veneto, my region, in recent weeks thousands of people have signed to hold a referendum for independence from Veneto and Italy.
Yesterday, in Veneto, in Lombardy and in all the northern regions, hundreds and thousands of people signed to have more autonomy from Rome.
But also in Flanders, in the Basque Country, citizens are clamoring for autonomy and independence from nation-states.
What does President Schulz say?
It requires a courageous commitment to clearly say no to all separatist tendencies.
His deputy Vidal Quadra, even worse, has called for the use of force against Catalan citizens.
Their statements are a most serious act, contrary to the principles of the democracy that we preach here and that we must defend.
I tell them that it will be the people who will write the future of the new Europe, not the bureaucrats in Brussels.
The path is already mapped out.
The austerity policy adopted to overcome the economic crisis has not yielded the expected results.
as was emphasized in the report by my colleague La Via, only by investing more selectively and supporting the ideal of a European budget that is sometimes too limited.
To support growth and employment, it will be possible to rebalance the economy of the Member States, thereby improving the situation of European citizens.
For this reason, I therefore cast my vote in favor.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the social and economic context in which the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014 is being discussed is rather problematic.

With member states engaged in making fiscal adjustments to their national budgets to shore up public finances, the European Union is seen in some cases as an entity that increases the financial burden on taxpayers.

For this reason, in order to truly emerge from the crisis and guarantee a better future for young Europeans, it will be of fundamental importance to support greater and more concrete investments in the sectors of training and development.
This is the charter of an institution whose budget reveals what it is, what it does, and above all, what it wants to do in the future.

We are faced with a crucial choice between a budget of survival, of dragging things along, perhaps a little less for everyone, or a budget of courage, of selective choices, of investments in employment, innovation and young people, that is, for the future of the European Union and its vocation for development.

Everyone should understand that, as my colleague Calfin, among others, has made very clear, Europe can now do what the states can no longer do for the economy, for regional development, for the territories where social cohesion is established or where the lives of the citizens we have discussed are destroyed.
Europe's major decisions are now at risk of being stifled by the bureaucratic disputes within the Council, and not just between beneficiary countries and net contributors.

We say that it is a false problem, because it is easy to demonstrate with figures, with numbers, not with words, for what has happened in the past, that the contributing countries, sometimes more than others, benefit from the convergence of economies and growth.
The Council is currently working on putting figures next to the various headings.

The war of positions has begun, with declarations and statements from certain states that view the budget as a trail of any expense that can be cut without remorse, which may even be useful in bolstering anti-European sentiment, which is easy to stir up during times of economic crisis.
It is a wrong position that does not help that integration that we are trying to achieve in other areas.
Dear colleagues, our Europe is still incomplete and mutilated, as many of us have said.
We adopted a stability pact, which was also meant to be a development pact, but we have become so stable that we are now in recession.
Here, let us at least take the opportunity of this budget, of this multi-annual framework, to make choices in the right direction.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the lack of information and awareness of one's rights, compounded by economic obstacles, is not a solution.
Language problems and the non-recognition of diplomas and qualifications are the most common problems that EU citizens encounter when residing, studying or working in another European Union country.
Unfortunately, there is still a lack of visibility of the notion of Union citizenship and its concrete benefits.
This is why I expressed my support for 2013 as the European Year of Citizens.

The primary objective is indeed to strengthen awareness of the rights associated with Union citizenship and to help citizens fully exercise their right to move and reside freely within the territories of the Member States.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the proliferation of innovative financial instruments poses numerous challenges in terms of regulation, governance and monitoring their effectiveness.
In fact, it is necessary to find a fair balance between the objectives of transparency and control, as well as a sufficient level of effectiveness and speed of implementation.

The introduction of such instruments at the European level is, however, of great importance, as it represents a means by which the European Union, especially in times of crisis, can stimulate investment in the economy.
real, in a manner consistent with its objectives, in a context where the continuous decrease in responses to the Community budget is juxtaposed with the constant growth of its political ambitions.
The Brussels I Regulation has undoubtedly been one of the most effective acts of European regulation for safety and security in the workplace.
of the Union's legislation, as it has laid the foundations for a European judicial area and ensured the rule of law among European citizens.
The dissemination of this regulation touches on fundamental issues for the development of European justice, including the extension of rules on the
on the jurisdiction of disputes with parties domiciled in third countries and agreements on the choice of jurisdiction.
I am convinced that the approval of the new regulation can ensure stronger consumer protection and greater legal certainty within the internal market, and for this reason I cast my vote in favour.

Mr President, Commissioner, Europe is now being called upon to take on a new task of coordinating industrial policies, and even the most staunch supporters of autonomy and private initiative are now calling for the exercise of this role.
Without greater Europeanization of national strategies, including in terms of employment protection, the current crisis cannot be overcome and there will be no recovery.
The car crisis is not just about overproduction capacity, it's about a dramatic loss of jobs.
But the crisis now seems structural and concerns the very fate of the car, of the product, as it is today.
We want to keep the car industry in Europe and we want to avoid dispersing the existing skills and know-how, the professional skills.
We therefore call for the initiation of a major restructuring and relaunch project, and for this to be done quickly, because the costs are proportional to the time taken.
Restructuring cannot be the result of fragmented national decisions or individual company actions alone.
At the very least, we must attempt to coordinate and guide this painful process at the community level, bringing the interested parties to the table through social dialogue.
producers, trade unions and individual country governments, providing support for research, innovation, human capital formation, retraining, and the necessary funds.
I know it will be a difficult task, because the national interests of individual companies are not aligned.

But since the competitive clash underway in the European Union is very ambiguous and sometimes risks being unfair, I think that in the end it is in the interest of all countries to have an effective community impulse and guidance to face the increasingly aggressive global market together.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the energy crisis has cost and is costing an extremely high price to all employment, to thousands of precarious workers but also stable and temporary workers, who are numerous in this sector.
The major steel groups are increasingly orienting themselves towards the Far East or the American continent, posing a major question about the direction of our development model.
I think that Europe must recover the idea that a manufacturing system like ours needs solid basic production capable of supplying the European internal market.
We must therefore defend this sector, the role of a stable steel industry, and we will support it, Commissioner, if we want to stop industrial decline.

I believe we need to move away from a dualism that isn't being discussed here tonight, but that is often heard in debates about this sector - a dualism between environmental supporters and workers' supporters - which is wrong because it doesn't allow us to see a future perspective.
An industry that sees steel production as an integral part needs advanced production systems, concrete and balanced solutions that safeguard different interests and diverse needs.

Therefore, a strong planning approach is needed, including at the European level, that focuses on sustainability, which, in my opinion, we must not abandon, as it represents a true added value with which we want to compete in the world, by supporting investments.

We have repeatedly mentioned new technologies, new processes, the upgrading of facilities for a European economy that makes effective use of resources, including energy resources, indeed starting with energy resources, and also the search for new and different materials.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, as we have recalled in this Chamber, next December the United Nations Agency dedicated to communication and information technologies will meet in Dubai for the World Conference on International Communications.
The subject is the renegotiation of international telecommunications regulations.

We cannot forget, and I am pleased with Commissioner Tajani's words, the work that has been done to date, which cannot be called into question, nor can we allow the authority of the European Union to be bypassed.

a supranational structure like the ITU, of which we know hundreds of states from all over the world are part, and many of which are known for problems related to democracy, transparency, and freedom of expression.
So it is not wrong to believe that the pillars of the Internet, namely freedom, participation, openness, and innovation, are in danger.

Therefore, I believe it is necessary to protect the role of the Internet and the role that the Internet can play in relaunching economic growth, but not only that, also in order to guarantee opportunities for everyone.
I therefore hope that the Commission will work towards ensuring that Europe in Dubai is united and speaks with one voice.

Many controversial proposals have been presented at the negotiating table of the World Conference on International Telecommunications, particularly those that envisage changes to Internet governance, which call into question net neutrality, with negative implications for consumers.
At risk, therefore, is the freedom of the Internet or, more precisely, the freedom of expression and data protection.
What some states have proposed would indeed allow a government to snoop not only on the communications of its own citizens, but even on the data that passes through its networks.
The step from here to the limitation of freedom of expression and censorship is extremely short and therefore I believe it is in contradiction with the fundamental principles of the European Union.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, I have expressed my support for the text of my colleague and in particular I agree with the rapporteur in emphasising the fundamental role played by national judges in the application of law within the Union.

I therefore consider it necessary to fully support the European Union's efforts to improve and coordinate training in the field of jurisdiction for judicial and administrative authorities and legal professionals.
All sector initiatives should also be intensified in order to fully realize the concept of a Union based on the rule of law.

Mr. President, Honorable Colleagues, in recent years, the extraction of so-called unconventional hydrocarbons, including gas and shale oil, has led to an unprecedented transformation in global energy markets.
Europe, in order to cope with this situation and be less dependent on hydrocarbon imports, will therefore have to rely on its potential gas and oil reserves.
In this regard, some Member States have already authorized the exploration for shale gas and are preparing for the extraction phase, should the discovery allow it.
In such a context, it becomes necessary to monitor the regulations concerning the extraction of shale gas within the borders of the Union, so that the effects of its extinction are not diminished.
The extractions, undoubtedly valid from an economic point of view, do not create environmental problems for the possible release of harmful substances into the groundwater or the atmosphere.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, I believe that today's meeting should be an opportunity to discuss Kazakhstan and the important agreement that the country is negotiating with the European Union in an objective manner.
Kazakhstan is a crucial country for the stability and strategic future of Central Asia and is an indisputable important economic and trade partner of the European Union.

This is a country that has already initiated a process of economic reforms and also a democratic process, but which still needs to make a great effort to bring these processes to a successful conclusion.

However, it is a country that, with this goal, persists in demonstrating its readiness for new and more robust reforms, and I believe that it is the task of the European Union to accompany these reforms.

For this reason, I am certain that the signing of this enhanced agreement will allow for progress, because its approval will strengthen an already solid and productive relationship and ensure ongoing assistance from the European Union.

I also remain convinced, and I believe this should have been even more emphasized in the report we will vote on tomorrow, that the improvement of progress on the path to democracy and human rights must be accompanied by a renewed and mutual commitment to open and constructive dialogue.

Our goal should not be to take a negative stance towards these and other countries in the face of the failure to immediately implement changes, our goal should be to support these countries' efforts to achieve the goal of respecting human rights principles as well.

Mr President, Commissioner, honourable Members, I would like to thank the rapporteurs for the reports we will be voting on tomorrow. Just a brief point on the spin-off and I would like to endorse what I have heard this evening as a unanimous voice from all my fellow Members.
But I wanted to focus on the Ferrera report, which I welcome and congratulate him on.
I wanted to say that with the past common fisheries policy, we have only contributed to increasing the gap between the institutions that regulate fishing and its real actors, namely the fishermen.

Unfortunately, until now in Europe, the lack of a proper definition of artisanal fishing has penalized those who have always viewed fishing as an activity tied to the traditions of their place, their seas, and their cuisine.

Thus grew the conviction that the European Commission's approach was to standardize all fishing in Europe under large-scale industrial fishing, following only market logic and not listening to the concerns of thousands of fishermen who, for a couple of...

For decades, they have been operating according to rules related to the preservation of the ecosystem, with which I can only agree, but which have never preserved the work activities of the microeconomy of artisanal fishing.
This own-initiative report is a strong signal to the Commission and could result in practical measures to benefit the micro-economy of fisheries.
The report, in fact, highlights a number of advantages of allocating a minimum amount to small-scale fishing from the European Fund.

Projects with integrated solutions that benefit the coastal community as a whole must be encouraged, and it will also be essential, Commissioner, to encourage young people's access to job opportunities.

We have discussed this sector several times in committee, because otherwise, not only will fishing likely die out due to depleted seas and fish stocks, but it will probably also die out because young people are no longer drawn to this sector.
This report is an opportunity to include training and incentive moments for young people who want to get closer to the sector.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, like many of my colleagues, today I ask the Council that made this proposal, but what do you intend to do, gentlemen of Europe?
Do you want to minimize it, freeze it in the future?
But it is that same Europe that then wants to relaunch itself with the Van Rompuy document on integration.
But with what consistency, I ask you, does Varro Poirier conduct these two dossiers?

And what consistency can citizens find between the decisions of July, employment and growth, the repeated calls for hope and the future in the European Union, which we also hear from the Council, and this violent fall then, in the name of realism, into a perspective of minimal survival?
How will it be possible, with these figures and these cuts, to turn the much-vaunted major reforms of cohesion and the CAP into concrete actions and active policies?
These are sincere questions, we would like a clear, honest answer, because there are signs of institutional schizophrenia here that Parliament no longer accepts, that citizens no longer accept.
Parliament wants consistency, it wants credibility.

The first criticism is that we are not even at the budget level, let alone growth and investment; we are at the 2008 budget. It must be acknowledged, however, that with regard to heading 1a, Van Rompuy's proposal overturns the scandalous Cypriot proposal.
It is true that here the role of the budget as an irreplaceable driver of growth in certain sectors is recognized, in addition to national budgets.

But let it be clear that growth and innovation must not come at the expense of other sectors that are also part of growth and jobs, such as cohesion policy and, dear gentlemen, agricultural policy, which has increased employment and is increasingly oriented towards innovation and the protection of the territory.

Our territory, growth and jobs, culture, education, transnational networks, the CEF and also solidarity and international development, human rights in the world and our contribution to the Millennium Goals.

Unfortunately, what we have before us is the usual spectacle of the Council: no vision, no guidance, a babble of competing national interests, an inextricable tangle of vetoes, expectations, and general discontent.
And Europe, unfortunately, is the big absentee.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, finning is an environmentally unacceptable practice, as it threatens the sustainability of certain shark species, which are in danger from this point of view.

This is both socially and economically unacceptable, as it involves the waste of a food product of commercial value, and ethically unacceptable, as it demonstrates a complete lack of respect for animal life.

Although this practice has been prohibited since 2003 in European waters and for the European fleet, the Commission has decided to present a proposal aimed at eliminating the exemption to the ban on removing shark fins on board Union fishing vessels.

This proposal, in addition to further ensuring that sharks receive the protection they need, will thus enable the European Union to actively contribute to the global effort underway to eradicate the cruel practice of shark finning in other parts of the world as well.
